Personal Finance
Loans
Student Loans
Learn all about student loans including where to get them, how to get them, and strategies to avoid massive loan debt by the time you graduate.
Student Loans
Understanding FAFSA: Unlock Federal and State Financial Aid
Private vs. Federal College Loans: What's the Difference?
How to Apply for Student Loans
Student Loan Interest Rates
How Long Does It Take to Pay Off Student Loan Debt?
Frequently Asked Questions
What are the four types of federal student loans?
The U.S. Department of Education currently offers direct subsidized loans, direct unsubsidized loans, direct PLUS loans, and direct consolidation loans. Subsidized loans are solely for eligible undergraduate students who demonstrate financial need to help cover the costs of a higher education, while unsubsidized loans are available for eligible undergraduate, graduate, and professional students, though eligibility isn’t based on financial need. PLUS loans are made to graduate or professional students as well as parents of dependent undergraduate students for education expenses not covered by other financial aid. A consolidation loan allows you to combine all of your eligible federal student loans into one loan with a sole loan servicer.
Learn More:
Subsidized vs. Unsubsidized Student Loans—Which Is Best?
Should you pay off your student loans early?
It depends on your financial circumstances. Since interest may accumulate on your student loans while you’re in school (depending on the type of loan), it may make sense to begin making payments toward your debt before the actual due date kicks in.
There are no penalties for making prepayments on either federal or private student loans, so if you are able it can save you some money to start early.
Learn More:
Managing Your Student Loans During College
What happens if you don’t pay off your student loan?
The first day following a missed student loan payment, your student loan becomes past due (i.e.,
delinquent
) until you either repay the past due amount or make other arrangements with your creditor. Remaining delinquent for 90 days or more will result in your loan servicer reporting the delinquency to the three major national credit bureaus. Following a certain period of delinquency, which varies based on the type of loan, there is also a risk of the loan going into
default
.
Learn More:
Student Loan Help: Free and Low-Cost Solutions to Out-of-Control Loans
Can student loans repayments come out of your retirement funds?
Per the
Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA)
, most employer-sponsored retirement plans, such as a 401(k), are protected from seizure by creditors in nearly all cases.
However, according to the Debt Collection Improvement Act of 1996, up to 15% of your Social Security payments can be garnished to repay your federal student loan(s) should you default. Fortunately, the amount garnished cannot reduce your monthly benefit payment below $750.
Learn More:
Heading Into Retirement With Student Loans
Key Terms
Education Loan
Federal Direct Loan Program
Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA)
FAFSA Award Letter
Deferment Period
PLUS Loan
Direct Consolidation Loan
Student Loan Interest Deduction
Education Loan
An education loan, more commonly known as a student loan, is an amount of money borrowed from a federal or private lender to pay for a higher education. This sum can be used to cover the cost of tuition, textbooks, other school supplies, and basic living expenses so that a student may focus on earning their degree. Generally speaking, federal student loans offer lower interest rates than their private counterparts.
Learn More
Federal Direct Loan Program
The William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program is a federal student loan program offered by the U.S. Department of Education. The Federal Direct Loan Program is available to eligible postsecondary students and their parents. Direct subsidized loans, direct unsubsidized loans, direct PLUS loans, and direct consolidation loans are all available through this program.
Learn More
Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA)
The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is an official form that must be filled out in order to receive financial aid from the federal government. To complete the FAFSA, you must provide information about yourself and your financial situation. The FAFSA is available starting Oct. 1 of the year prior to enrollment, and the federal due date is June 30 of the academic year (some colleges and/or states have their own deadlines).
Learn More
FAFSA Award Letter
A FAFSA award letter is provided by the colleges that are listed on your FAFSA form and details the cost of attendance for an academic year and your eligibility for any grants, loans, etc. Most colleges send out award letters alongside their admission offer letters. Although colleges have access to your FAFSA information a day after it’s processed, the timeframes for reviewing your FAFSA information may vary from one university to another.
Learn More
Deferment Period
A deferment period is an amount of time where a borrower isn't required to repay their loan's principal or interest. Deferment periods vary based on the type of loan; student loans can only be deferred for up to three years. Depending on the type of student loan, you may still have to pay down the interest that accrues during the deferment period.
Learn More
PLUS Loan
A PLUS loan is offered to graduate & professional students and the parents of dependent undergraduates. While eligibility isn’t based on financial need, a credit check is required, and borrowers with an adverse credit history won’t be eligible without meeting other criteria.
The max amount available to you will be based on your chosen college's cost of attendance minus any financial aid you’ve received.
Learn More
Direct Consolidation Loan
A direct consolidation loan allows you to combine all of your eligible federal student loans into just one loan with a sole loan servicer.
Your consolidated loan will have a fixed interest rate based on the average of the original loans’ interest rates. Consolidating multiple loans can be accomplished at no cost to you and allows you to reduce your number of monthly payments.
Learn More
Student Loan Interest Deduction
A student loan interest deduction allows you to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest paid on qualified student loans during the tax year. The deduction is only available if you meet certain eligibility criteria, and it’s gradually reduced as your modified adjusted gross income (MAGI) reaches its annual limit. This interest deduction is claimed as an adjustment to income, so it don't need to itemized on your income tax returns.
Learn More

Economy
The economy is the total of all activities related to the production, sale, distribution, exchange, and consumption of limited resources by a group of people living and operating within it.
Guide to the Economy
The Top 25 Economies in the World
Understanding How Economies Form and Drive Growth
How Education and Training Affect the Economy
Median Income by State
Understanding Market Economy: History, Features & Function
Frequently Asked Questions
What is a command economy?
In a command economy, a centralized government controls the means of production and it decides the output levels for that production. This type of economy is often associated with communist nations. The advantages of this approach include better equality and lower unemployment, but there is often a lack of efficiency or innovation in those economies.
Learn More:
Command Economy: Advantages and Disadvantages
What is a market economy?
A market economy, or free economy, is directed through the laws of supply and demand to set the prices and quantities for most goods and services. Most developed nations are technically mixed economies because they blend free markets with some government interference such as industrial subsidies, licensing, and price fixing.
Learn More:
Market Economy vs. Command Economy: What's the Difference?
What does inflation do to an economy?
Inflation means the rate at which the same goods and services come to cost more. If a person's income doesn't keep up with inflation, it can decrease your purchasing power. It can also lower the value of Treasury bonds. But if some level of inflation is expected, it can drive consumer spending, which drives economic growth.
Learn More:
When Is Inflation Good for the Economy
How stocks help the economy
When the price of a large number of stocks is on the rise, it can lead to higher consumer and business confidence, higher spending on big-ticket items such as cars and houses, and an increase in investors entering the stock market. These factors can all lead to greater economic development of a country.
Learn More:
What Does the Term 'Invisible Hand' Refer to in an Economy?
What type of economy does the U.S. have?
The United States has a mixed economy. It combines elements of a command economy with a market economy. A mixed economy allows for government oversight and regulation to achieve public good while also allowing things like consumer goods and services to be regulated by the laws of supply and demand.
Learn More:
Is the United States a Market Economy or a Mixed Economy?
Key Terms
Economy
Money
Trade
Knowledge Economy
Wealth
Law of Supply and Demand
Inflation
Organized Labor
Sluggish Economy
Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
Economy
An economy encompasses all activity related to the production, consumption, trade, and distribution of available goods and services. The management of those resources is used to satisfy the needs of the people, businesses, organizations, and governments in a specific area.
Learn More
Money
Currency, or money, is a generally accepted, recognized, and centralized medium of exchange that market participants use to engage in transactions for goods and services in an economy. Each government has its own money system that is monitored by a central authority.
Learn More
Trade
The buying, selling, or bartering of goods and services is known as trade. In an economy, a trade takes place between a producer and a consumer, usually in exchange for money. An exchange of goods and services between two countries is international trade.
Learn More
Knowledge Economy
A knowledge economy is a system of consumption and production based on the intangible assets of intellectual capital. It refers to the ability to capitalize on scientific discoveries and academic research, and has come to represent a large component of all economic activity in developed countries.
Learn More
Wealth
Wealthy is an abundant supply of valuable economic assets or resources owned by a person, company, community, or nation. It can be determined by subtracting debt from the total market value of all physical and intangible assets.
Learn More
Law of Supply and Demand
The law of supply and demand is an economic theory based on two separate "laws" that explain the interaction between the sellers of a resource and the buyers of that resource. The theory defines the relationship between the price of a given good or product and the willingness of people to either buy or sell it. Generally, as the price increases, people are willing to supply more and demand less and vice versa when the price falls.
Learn More
Inflation
A decline of the
purchasing power
of a specific currency over time is known as inflation. You can see the rate of decline reflected in the increase of an average price level of a
basket of selected goods
and services in an economy over a specified period of time. The rise in the general level of prices, often expressed as a percentage, means that a unit of currency effectively buys less than it did in prior periods.
Learn More
Organized Labor
An association of workers united as a single entity, known as organized labor or a union, seek to improve the economic status and working conditions of employees through collective bargaining with management.
Learn More
Sluggish Economy
The colloquial phrase "sluggish economy" is not an exact and quantifiable thing. It is derived from an analogy to a slug and refers to an economy in which growth is slow in macroeconomic terms. It can be used to describe an entire economy or a segment of it.
Learn More
Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
Gross domestic product (GDP) is a broad measure of a country's overall domestic production and a measure of that country's overall economic health. It is calculated by the total monetary or market value of all the finished goods and services produced within a country’s borders in a specific time period.
Learn More
Visitor Numbers in Las Vegas Plummet, Sparking Worries About US Economic Health
How Tariffs are Affecting Job Prospects for the Class of 2025

Best Crypto Exchanges and Apps for January 2026
By
Will Baker
Full Bio
Will Baker is a full-time associate editor at Investopedia. He has over a decade of experience as a writer and editor, covering investing, trading, and other aspects of financial journalism. Before working at Investopedia, Will was the content writer for Simpler Trading. He is a U.S. Navy veteran and has a bachelor's degree from the University of Central Florida.
Learn about our
editorial policies
Updated December 30, 2025
Fact checked by
Matthew M Klammer
Fact checked by
Matthew M Klammer
Full Bio
With practical experience running his own IT business and an education in the liberal arts, Matthew Klammer had become well-accustomed to the difficulties of research. From providing POS systems to small tourist shops to data security and account management Matthew has provided business solutions to many individuals.
Learn about our
editorial policies
Best Crypto Exchanges and Apps for January 2026
View All
Best Crypto Exchanges and Apps for January 2026
Top Picks
Kraken
Gemini
Coinbase
See More (2)
Crypto.com
BitMart
Why Trust Us
Methodology
If you are looking to buy and sell digital currencies such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other popular but smaller coins, the best crypto exchanges provide powerful trading tools, basic-to-advanced order types, a large selection of cryptocurrencies, and many more features and services. Investopedia’s in-house staff of researchers and editors evaluated 14 crypto exchanges based on 27 weighted criteria critical to cryptocurrency traders' success.
Our exhaustive research has revealed that Kraken is best for users seeking low fees. Experienced traders who value a high degree of platform security may want to consider Gemini, while Coinbase is best for beginners. Crypto.com is best for mobile users who often trade on the go. It is also the best platform for Bitcoin-focused traders and investors. Last but not least, cryptocurrency enthusiasts seeking digital assets not found anywhere else will find that BitMart is best for altcoins.
Best Crypto Exchanges and Apps for January 2026
Best for Low Fees:
Kraken
Best For Security, Best for Experienced Traders:
Gemini
Best for Beginners:
Coinbase
Best Mobile App, Best for Bitcoin:
Crypto.com
Best for Altcoins:
BitMart
Important
Investing in cryptocurrencies,
Decentralized Finance (DeFi)
, and other
Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs)
is highly risky and speculative, and the markets can be extremely volatile. Consult with a qualified professional before making any financial decisions. This article is not a recommendation by Investopedia or the writer to invest in cryptocurrencies, nor can the accuracy or timeliness of the information be guaranteed.
Open a New Account
Advertiser Disclosure
×
The offers that appear in this table are from partnerships from which Investopedia receives compensation. This compensation may impact how and where listings appear. Investopedia does not include all offers available in the marketplace.
Institution
Fees
Min. to Open
Highlights
Best for Low Fees
:
Kraken
Kraken
Minimum deposit:
$10
Maker fees:
0.00% to 0.25% on Kraken Pro
Taker fees:
0.08% to 0.40% on Kraken Pro
Available cryptocurrencies:
540+
Open Account
(opens in a new tab)
Why We Chose It
The Kraken crypto exchange is Investopedia’s choice for low fees. Investors who value low cost but need access to high-quality amenities and resources won’t find a better exchange that consistently offers both. With a minimum deposit of just $10, Prospective clients can set up an account and start trading their favorite cryptocurrency.
Pros & Cons
Pros
Low fees for beginning and advanced cryptocurrency traders
A good selection of educational resources and research amenities
Access to web, desktop, mobile, and Kraken Pro platform
Cons
Kraken is not available in all 50 U.S. states
Does not offer FDIC or SIPC insurance or other criminal insurance.
Does not allow options trading for cryptocurrency
Overview
Kraken was founded in 2011. While the company has gone fully remote, its head office is in San Francisco, CA.
Aside from its digital presence, Kraken operates worldwide in over 190 countries, services over 15 million clients, and has established itself as one of the premier cryptocurrency exchanges that offer the best low-fee service.
Kraken offers two platforms: a basic and a pro version. Clients utilizing the basic version can expect to pay the following fees: a fixed 1% trading fee, payment fees, and a spread. Regarding Kraken Pro, clients will pay maker fees between 0.00% and 0.25% and taker fees between 0.08% and 0.40%. The fee will be dependent upon the users' 30-day trading volume. Other fees, such as deposit and address setup fees, come at no extra cost.
In addition to its low-fee structure, Kraken offers a unique service that caters to multiple types of clients at various skill levels.
For instance, Kraken’s regular platform enables beginning and low-volume traders to start trading and storing their cryptocurrency with a $10 minimum deposit, access to over 540 cryptocurrency assets, an excellent selection of educational and news content, and the ability to create and utilize Kraken's exclusive wallet.
Advanced traders who need more sophisticated features should consider Kraken Pro. This platform is designed for traders who need access to advanced order types, charting, and screening capabilities not offered on the original platform.
The Kraken Pro's best feature is that it’s free to use. However, Kraken comes with potential drawbacks. While Kraken operates in many countries, the exchange is not available in all 50 U.S. states, such as Washington, New York, and Maine. Furthermore, in many other states, additional restrictions apply to activities such as staking, payment services, funding, and custody. Prospective clients interested in a specific service should check if it is legal in their respective state.
It’s also important to note that Kraken does not offer any insurance for its users.
Read the
full Kraken review
Best For Security
,
Best for Experienced Traders
:
Gemini
Gemini
Minimum deposit:
$0.00
Maker fees:
0.00% to 0.20%
Taker fees:
0.03% to 0.40%
Available cryptocurrencies:
70+
Open Account
(opens in a new tab)
Why We Chose It
Best For Security
Gemini is our top choice for security. The crypto exchange has sound security standards, a commitment to compliance, and third-party audits that ensure its security infrastructure operates at a high level.
It’s also one of the few crypto exchanges to offer FDIC and crypto insurance to help further safeguard traders’ accounts.
Best for Experienced Traders
In addition to being our choice for security, Gemini is also our top choice for experienced traders due to its ActiveTrader software. The platform offers experienced users the ability to conduct advanced charting techniques, use advanced
order types
, and trade futures and perpetual contracts.
Pros & Cons
Pros
Highly secure and compliant platform
Available in all 50 U.S. states
Pass-through FDIC insurance for uninvested cash and crypto insurance
Cons
Offers a low number of cryptocurrencies
Customer support only has a request form
Complex fee structure
Overview
Gemini was founded in 2014 and is currently headquartered in New York, N.Y.
Due to its high security standards, Gemini is our choice for users who value security for their cryptocurrency holdings. By default, user accounts are equipped with two-factor authentication. However, Gemini also supports external hardware security keys, such as YubiKey, to secure accounts further.
Gemini holds most customer assets in offshore cold storage, and it works to facilitate easy transfers of assets between the exchange and consumer wallets. Gemini also subjects itself to routine third-party audits and affirms that it has completed SOC 1 and SOC 2 Type 2 exams and its ISO 27001 certification.
Users also have the option to store their cryptocurrency in either Gemini’s hot wallet, which is insured, or its cold wallet.
Gemini is also our choice for experienced crypto traders. While high-net-worth individuals can enjoy its high-security standards, they can also appreciate the advanced software it offers with its trademarked tool, ActiveTrader. Even though it offers more than 70 cryptocurrencies, it's still considered a low amount for a major crypto exchange. However, Gemini’s ActiveTrader deserves recognition as a highly advanced platform capable of reaching trade execution speeds of 65 microseconds. Experienced traders also have access to high-risk assets such as perpetual contracts and indices.
ActiveTrader also provides advanced charting and order types that further assist traders in their cryptocurrency ventures.
Gemini does have some drawbacks, most notably its fee structure, as it can be complex. For ActiveTrader, depending on your 30-day trade volume, maker fees can range from 0.00% to 0.20%, while taker fees can range from 0.03% to 0.40%.
Gemini's fee schedule for basic order types, such as instant and recurring orders, will cost clients a 1.49% transaction fee combined with a 1% convenience fee. Limit orders will cost a 1.49% transaction fee, but do not have a convenience fee.
Additionally, the type of order you use to execute a trade can affect the total cost. Other fees include a 2.50% fiat transfer fee for using PayPal and a $25 wire transfer fee for fiat withdrawals.
Customer support should also be noted, as traders must submit a form to deal with issues like account management and fraud.
Best for Beginners
:
Coinbase
Coinbase
Minimum deposit:
$0.00
Maker fees:
0.00% to 0.40%
Taker fees:
0.05% to 0.60%
Available cryptocurrencies:
300+
Open Account
(opens in a new tab)
On with Coinbase
Why We Chose It
Coinbase is best for beginners due to its sleek user interface, solid security infrastructure, and a reasonable fee structure that is easy to understand. While Coinbase offers an excellent service for investors new to crypto trading, the company also provides more advanced features, which are nonetheless vital for beginning crypto traders. With Coinbase's comprehensive educational resources, beginners can enhance their skills and utilize Coinbase’s more
advanced trading tools
when they are ready, without having to jump to another exchange that caters to more experienced traders.
Pros & Cons
Pros
Excellent educational and research resources
Reasonable fee structure and a good selection of cryptocurrency
Available in 172 countries and offers access to web, desktop, and mobile platforms
Cons
It may not be a good fit for established traders
Does not offer margin or option trading and only provides future trading on select crypto
Must chat or request a call when contacting customer service
Overview
Coinbase is headquartered in San Francisco and was founded in 2012.
Since its inception as a cryptocurrency exchange, Coinbase has become one of the premier leaders in the cryptocurrency space and has done the one thing many crypto exchanges fail to do: cater to beginner crypto investors.
Cryptocurrency is a complicated
alternative investment
that requires careful study by traders. However, Coinbase’s educational resources, which cover basic and advanced trading topics, can help clarify its complexity.
In addition, Coinbase offers two charting versions: a basic and an advanced version.
The basic version is a simple chart with essential data such as market cap, volume, and other metrics that beginning traders will find valuable.
However, it does not provide any charting tools, which is why Coinbase also has an advanced version.
The advanced version offers charting features such as Fibonacci, drawing tools, and projections. Even with advanced trading software, Coinbase may not be a great fit even for experienced traders, as the exchange lacks options and margin trading and only offers futures trading on specific coins.
Investors who open an account with Coinbase will see that it has a reasonable fee structure. Its maker fee ranges between 0.00% to 0.40%, and its taker fees are 0.05% to 0.60%.
Also, users can trade more than 300 cryptocurrencies while being able to survey over 19,000 digital assets.
While Coinbase provides web, desktop, and mobile platforms, its customer service could be better.
Users can contact a service rep through chat or request a call for further assistance.
Read our full
Coinbase review
.
Important
On May 11, 2025, Coinbase received an email communication from a threat actor notifying the company that internal data and customer information, including names, contact details, partial SSNs, and transaction history, had been accessed after allegedly bribing non-U.S. contractors. The attacker demanded payment to keep the data private. Coinbase says no passwords or funds were compromised and has not paid the ransom.
Best Mobile App
,
Best for Bitcoin
:
Crypto.com
Crypto.com
Minimum deposit:
$20
Maker fees:
0.08% to 0.25%
Taker fees:
0.18% to 0.50%
Available cryptocurrencies:
400+
Open Account
(opens in a new tab)
Why We Chose It
Best Mobile App
Crypto.com is our choice for the best mobile app provider due to its major focus on its mobile platform and all that that entails. Crypto traders can buy, sell, use, and trade crypto from the palms of their hands.
Best for Bitcoin
Crypto.com is also our choice for Bitcoin traders and investors due to its reasonable fee structure and excellent security infrastructure, which is important to many Bitcoin investors and users. In addition, Crypto.com provides crypto traders with Bitcoin options and futures.
Pros & Cons
Pros
Allows Bitcoin options and futures
Reasonable fee structure and a good selection of cryptocurrency
Excellent mobile platform and debit card program
Cons
Available in fewer than 100 countries
Only offers chat service for assistance
Crypto.com only provides access to a hot wallet
Overview
Crypto.com, headquartered in the Central Region of Singapore, boasts an impressive customer base of over 150 million users in more than 100 countries, which isn’t bad for a company that was founded in 2016.
The main reason why Crypto.com is so popular goes far beyond its marketing campaigns. It's one of the best crypto exchanges for mobile-first traders and Bitcoin holders.
Mobile users considering Crypto.com can expect a sleek and fully intuitive mobile platform that offers more than convenience. Mobile users have access to more than 400 cryptocurrencies. Depending on the eligible cryptocurrency, users can earn rewards through Crypto.com’s Earn program and its Staking program.
In addition to buying, selling, and using cryptocurrency as well as trading derivatives, Crypto.com also provides its mobile users with sophisticated trading features, allowing them to automate their trades. Furthermore, Crypto.com includes access to its Visa debit card, a cryptocurrency-connected card enabling users to easily use their crypto to buy goods and services on the private market.
Along with its mobile capabilities, Crypto.com is also best for Bitcoin. The platform offers a wide array of trading, from derivatives to regular long-term investments. The company has a reasonable fee structure, which also applies to its mobile platform. However, depending on their 30-day trade volume, users can expect maker fees to be between 0.08% and 0.25% and taker fees to be between 0.18% and 0.50%. VIP users who hold a tiered amount of
Cronos (CRO)
can enjoy additional benefits, such as discounts on maker/taker fees and debit card rewards.
Bitcoin traders will also have access to Bitcoin options and futures, which is an important feature for traders and investors alike.
Before users sign up for an account, they should consider the downsides. For instance, Crypto.com is not readily available in many countries. Before committing to opening an account, you should check to see if Crypto.com legally operates in your geographical location. While Crypto.com has an excellent support center to help users resolve issues on their own, it only provides access to a live chat feature for further assistance.
Best for Altcoins
:
BitMart
Simply Recipes / Alison Bickel.
BitMart
Minimum deposit:
Not publicly disclosed
Maker fees:
Not publicly disclosed
Taker fees:
Not publicly disclosed
Available cryptocurrencies:
1,700+
Open Account
(opens in a new tab)
Why We Chose It
Bitmart, which offers over 1,700 cryptocurrencies, is our top choice as the best crypto exchange for
altcoins
. While the exchange lacks fundamental trading features, it's an excellent plateform to buy cryptocurrency that traders would not usually have to access on other exchanges.
Pros & Cons
Pros
Access to over 1,700 cryptocurrencies
Allows social trading through its copy-trading feature
BitMart Academy provides excellent educational resources
Cons
Does not display its security infrastructure
Its fee structure is not publicly disclosed without an account
Only supports crypto deposits to fund account
Overview
BitMart, founded in 2017 and headquartered in New York, N.Y., is our top choice for altcoins due to its accessibility to over 1,700 tradable cryptocurrencies.
While still offering access to the most important coins on the market, such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Solana, it provides other coins that may be difficult to find on other exchanges. It's important to note that cryptocurrency poses significant risks even with established digital coins. Smaller, less established coins pose even more risks, with liquidity and market manipulation being a serious concern for crypto holders.
BitMart also offers its users an interesting way to trade cryptocurrency: copy trading. BitMart users can access statistics for its top traders and see metrics such as
return on investment (ROI)
for cryptos they trade, along with their trading history and current trade positions. However, traders should remember that past success does not automatically lead to future gains and should proceed cautiously.
While BitMart has advanced charting capabilities, it’s only for futures trading.
In addition, BitMart does not offer some of the order types that certain competitors offer. To date, BitMart only provides two order types: market and limit orders.
Through BitMart Academy, the exchange offers excellent educational resources that cover various topics, from basic knowledge to more complex subjects. While it provides a robust selection of crypto, there are some drawbacks. Its fee structure is not publicly disclosed withount an account. Prospective customers will need to create one before they can see BitMart's fee structure. In addition, the only way to fund a new account is to transfer crypto from a wallet or another exchange.
BitMart claims to have an advanced risk control system with multi-signature technologies and a hybrid hot and cold wallet storage.
Unlike some competitors, BitMart does not reveal its security infrastructure for users' accounts. For instance, it does not publicly state its security certifications or disclose whether it subjects itself to third-party audits. We can confirm that the company equips users with multifactor authentication.
Read the full
BitMart review
.
Why You Should Trust Us
Investopedia launched in 1999, and since 2020, we have independently researched 14 cryptocurrency exchanges currently operating in the industry. To choose the best cryptocurrency, we analyzed nearly 450 key data points, including fees, available cryptocurrencies, trading features, security standards, and more, to bring together the list presented to you now. This way, readers interested in opening an account with a crypto exchange can choose the best company that will fit their financial needs and standards.
How We Picked the Best Cryptocurrency Exchanges and Apps
Investopedia's in-house team of researchers collected nearly 450 data points through online research of 14 leading cryptocurrency exchange provider websites. To fill in any gaps, our research team reached out to the individual exchanges. In some instances, our researchers did much deeper online research to get the information they needed to complete the data collection. The data collection process spanned from Feb. 7, 2025 to Feb 11, 2025.
We then developed a proprietary model that scored each company to rate its performance across four major categories and 29 weighted criteria to find the best cryptocurrency exchange companies. The score for each company’s overall star rating is a weighted average of the criteria in the following categories:
Trading Features: 30%
Fees: 28%
Security: 21%
Transparency: 21%
Through our research, Investopedia has provided you with a list of the best crypto exchanges, guided by data-driven analysis and an unbiased and fair approach to helping readers find the best crypto exchange.
Read our full detailed methodology
.
Everything You Need to Know About Cryptocurrency Exchanges
Investopedia / Julie Bang
Article Sources
Investopedia requires writers to use primary sources to support their work. These include white papers, government data, original reporting, and interviews with industry experts. of

and

available!

What Is the Jones Act?
April 12, 2025								    In
Yacht Insurance
What Is the Jones Act? A Guide for Yacht Owners
The Jones Act
, formally known as the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, is one of the most critical pieces of legislation in U.S. maritime law. While you may have heard this term within shipping, boating, or insurance discussions, understanding its wide-reaching implications is essential, especially if you’re a yacht owner or maritime professional with captain/crew exposures.
Below, we explore key aspects of the Jones Act to help you understand your obligations, protect your crew, and ensure compliance with this federal law.
If you’re a
yacht owner
looking to ensure comprehensive protection for your vessel and crew, we invite you to contact our marine insurance advisors. They can provide a
tailored yacht insurance
quote with crew coverage, ensuring you have the proper protection.
What Is the Jones Act?
The Jones Act is a federal law designed to protect U.S.-flagged vessels, their operators, and their crews. It governs coastwise trade and establishes specific requirements for ships operating between U.S. ports or conducting domestic trade. It was enacted by the U.S. Congress to stimulate the shipping industry in the wake of World War I.
Here are some basic principles of the law:
U.S.-built ships must transport goods or passengers between U.S. ports.
Companies operating under the Jones Act must employ U.S. citizens or permanent residents.
The Act prioritizes the interests of the American Merchant Marine and national security in a global shipping industry.
For yacht owners, one of the most critical aspects of the Jones Act is its focus on safety and working conditions for maritime workers. Let’s take a closer look at how this legislation can impact your responsibilities as a yacht owner.
1. Captain/Crew Protections
The Jones Act provides workers with necessary legal rights, including your yacht’s captain and crew. If a crew member sustains injuries while working on your vessel, they have the right to file claims for compensation. These claims often include
damages for medical expenses
, lost wages, and even pain and suffering.
If your captain or crew members feel unsupported, their dissatisfaction could escalate into legal claims. Protecting your crew isn’t just about compliance—it’s about preserving harmony and professionalism aboard your vessel.
Key Tip:
Make sure your insurance policy provides comprehensive captain/crew coverage to meet these obligations.
2. Liability and Negligence
Under the Jones Act, yacht owners can be held responsible for injuries caused by negligence or unsafe conditions on board. This means it’s your responsibility to:
Ensure proper safety measures are in place.
Conduct routine inspections for potential hazards.
Maintain your vessel’s overall seaworthiness.
Failing to operate a safe and secure yacht puts your crew at risk and exposes you to expensive legal claims.
Insurance Tip:
Many yacht insurance policies offer liability protections to reduce financial risks from negligence claims. Speak to a marine insurance professional to ensure your yacht’s policy includes this crucial coverage.
3. Maintenance and Cure
One of the essential provisions of the Jones Act is the requirement to provide “maintenance and cure” for injured crew members.
Maintenance
covers the crew member’s daily living expenses while recovering.
Cure
pays for their medical treatment until they reach maximum medical improvement (MMI).
This obligation applies regardless of fault, so even if the crew member’s injury wasn’t caused by negligence, as a yacht owner, you’re still responsible. Coverage for maintenance and cure claims helps ensure your yacht operation remains financially sustainable in the event of crew injuries.
4. Obligation to Provide Captain/Crew Coverage
Providing comprehensive insurance coverage for your captain and crew isn’t optional—it’s a legal and moral obligation.
This coverage should include protection for:
Injury due to negligence
Claims about safety in the work environment
Claims for lost wages, pain and suffering, or disability
Maintenance and cure obligations
Third-party passenger liability, if applicable
By ensuring proper insurance coverage, you safeguard your crew’s well-being and protect your financial interests.
Proactive Measure:
Consult an experienced marine insurance provider to create a policy tailored to your yacht’s unique needs.
5. Jones Act Requirements for Vessels
While the Jones Act primarily applies to
commercial vessels
, its focus on crew protections and overall safety extends to yacht owners with captain and crew exposures.
Additionally, the law emphasizes adherence to coastwise laws, such as hiring U.S. citizens or permanent residents as crew members. Special cases like transporting goods or docking in Puerto Rico, Hawaii, Alaska, or along coastlines may invoke specific Jones Act rules.
Yacht owners must take these regulations seriously to avoid non-compliance.
6. Seaworthiness Requirement
The Jones Act includes an implied warranty of seaworthiness, meaning that as a yacht owner, you are obligated to ensure that your vessel is reasonably fit for its intended use. This includes keeping the vessel safe for the captain/crew to work on.
If a captain/crew member is injured due to the vessel’s unseaworthiness, they may have grounds to file a negligence claim for which the yacht owner would be liable. In some instances, a judgment could be placed against the vessel itself.
7. Economic and Security Implications
The Jones Act is a central piece of legislation for protecting the rights and safety of U.S. maritime workers, including your yacht’s captain/crew. The Act maintains a robust and regulated maritime workforce, thus supporting the domestic maritime industry overall. Ensuring compliance and understanding your responsibilities under the Jones Act helps you provide a safe and secure environment for your captain/crew while minimizing potential liabilities.
8. Consequences of Not Providing Coverage
Failing to meet your obligations as stipulated under the Jones Act can result in:
Costly lawsuits from crew members seeking compensation.
Personal liability, with significant out-of-pocket expenses.
Consequences that may financially jeopardize your vessel’s operation.
By understanding your responsibilities and securing robust insurance coverage, you can avoid these penalties while fostering trust and security among your crew.
Secure Your Vessel’s Future
Interested in learning more about how the Jones Act applies to your yacht? W3 Insurance’s team of marine insurance experts is here to help.
Contact us
today for a consultation and customized yacht insurance quotes that meet your needs.
This overview is intended for informational purposes only and should not be considered legal advice. For specific legal guidance, please consult a qualified attorney familiar with maritime law. Founded in 1925, WWW Insurance has a rich history of providing quality service and an unwavering commitment to its clients and community.
FAQs about the Jones Act
What Is the Jones Act in Simple Terms?
The Jones Act, also known as the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, sets requirements for U.S. vessels and protects maritime workers, enabling them to seek compensation for on-the-job injuries.
Who Benefits from the Jones Act?
The Act benefits U.S. maritime workers, including captains and crew members. It also supports national security by safeguarding domestic shipping and strengthening the U.S. merchant fleet.
Is the Jones Act Applicable in Puerto Rico?
Yes, the law applies to Puerto Rico, restricting non-U.S.-flagged ships or foreign-flag vessels from transporting goods between U.S. and Puerto Rican ports.
Can the Jones Act Be Waived?
A waiver of the Jones Act can be granted during national emergencies or times of war, but these waivers are temporary and subject to conditions set by Homeland Security. Requests for waivers of specific provisions of the Act are reviewed by the U.S. Maritime Administration (MARAD) on a case-by-case basis.
Why Is the Jones Act Controversial?
Critics argue that the Act increases shipping costs by requiring goods to be transported on U.S.-owned and operated vessels, limiting competition from foreign ships in the U.S. economy. However, supporters view it as vital for protecting national security and the U.S. maritime industry.

Everything You Need to Know to Own a Boat in Florida
August 12, 2022								    In
Boat Insurance
Boat Ownership
Florida Boating
The state of Florida is made up of close to 19% water. From the marshy Everglades to the tarpon-rich waters near Boca Grande, it’s a boater’s paradise. Join the ranks of those discovering the restorative nature of boat life.
Here is everything you need to know about owning a boat in Florida.
Basic Boat Safety Tips
The number one most important element to consider when purchasing a boat in Florida is the boating prowess of the owner. That’s right: before you consider engines, hulls, power poles, or any navigational equipment, be honest about your experience level and your commitment to the craft. Purchase a boat you are comfortable captaining. A vessel that is too large, or that demands more than your training level, may leave you sitting on the shore, uncertain. Research the different types of boats thoroughly and select one that you feel confident driving.
Having a high level of confidence regarding the craft you captain is the most basic of basic boat safety tips. The next ‘must have’ element for every boat owner is the
boat safety kit
, which should always remain aboard.
Just as a Florida homeowner is advised to keep a hurricane preparedness kit just in case, so too must the Florida boat owner have a selection of items that help in the event of an accident or loss of power.
Common safety kit items
Flashlight (and batteries)
– Should your vessel break down in the nighttime hours, you’ll be glad to have the illumination.
Emergency radio
– We’ve all been in situations without a phone charger when we really need it. The emergency radio is there even if your cell phone isn’t – a link between you and those on shore.
Mirror for signaling and whistle for alerting
– Hold a mirror up to the sun, and you can deflect that sunlight far away. Even if your electronic equipment fails, that signal can be seen for miles. A whistle is a simple object that can help to alert others of your presence and need for help.
Properly prepared first aid kit
– There are many different types of first aid kits. Compile your own or purchase a kit specifically packed for Florida boaters. Inside, you’ll find the usual bandages, ointments, etc. We recommend adding sunscreen to the mix (that Florida sun can be brutal, and if you’re stranded, you’ll be glad to have it).
Fire extinguisher and garbage bags
– The need for the fire extinguisher is apparent, but garbage bags? – Yes, they are a worthy addition to the Florida boater safety kit. Use garbage bags as ponchos if it rains or to help conserve heat in cold weather.
Life jackets
– There needs to be one
life jacket
for every person aboard, regardless of age, even if they are expert swimmers. They should be approved by the U.S. Coast Guard.
Duct tape, buckets, and ropes
– Duct tape might not fix everything, but it can plug a small leak and give you enough time to get your craft back to shore. A simple bucket plays an important role if you need to bail out. And ropes are a must on any craft, at least to tie up to docks and rescue an overboard passenger.
Now that you have the items necessary to make up a Florida boat safety kit, it’s time to educate yourself regarding active, in-the-moment boat safety practices. Hopefully, if you follow the guidance of your boating safety class, you will never need the safety kit at all.
Recommended Boating Safety Courses
Did you know that you are
required to take a boat safety course
? If you are operating a motorized boat of more than 10 horsepower and were born during or after 1988, you are required to do so – an important part of keeping our waterways safe.
Look for a course that is Florida-approved; different options exist, including online selections. We suggest this one from
Boat Ed
. You can also peruse the list curated by the
Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission
for a solid list of options.
After you’ve aced your Florida boating safety course, make sure you know what to do if your boat breaks down or is involved in an accident. Knowledge gives peace of mind–that’s why we’ve compiled this boating accident and breakdown guide for a quick snapshot regarding what to do if your Florida boat runs into trouble.
Boating Accident and Breakdown Guide
Should a boating accident or breakdown occur, do an immediate check of everyone aboard for injury and to see what medical attention, if any, is needed. Break out the Florida boat first aid kit and tend to any wounds. Then, call for help using your cell phone or the emergency radio aboard.
What to do when involved in a boating accident
Document
the moment as much as possible. In the frenzy of stress that always accompanies a boating accident, major details can be lost. Take pictures of any damage and, instead of writing things down, you can dictate what happened and save the recording in your phone.
Determine if the U.S. Coast Guard should be notified
.
Call your marine insurance agent
and let them know what has happened. Hopefully, you’ve opted for comprehensive insurance protection that has you, your passengers, and your beloved boat covered.
What to do in the event of a breakdown
Try to move your craft out of the way
, if possible, if you are on a heavily-traveled waterway. This could save your boat from a collision.
Call the nearest harbor master,
or break out the emergency radio and call for help. Different tow services exist to help boaters who are stranded, or the Coast Guard may come to your aid if appropriate.
Where to store your boat
It’s important to know what to do
on
the water, but how are you protecting your boat when you’re
not
exploring the Florida waterways? There are several options available to you.
Storing your boat in Florida is quite easy. You could leave it outside your residence–keeping the vessel nearby and avoiding marina fees There are some drawbacks to this commonsense approach, however.
Exposing your craft to the elements
is a surefire way for it to deteriorate more quickly. A pervasive example of this is upholstery. Even the most watertight boat cushions are going to eventually disintegrate, and the more you expose a boat to the elements, the quicker this will occur. You could keep your boat in the garage, of course, but the vessel will take up most of that valuable storage and parking space.
Lift storage
Perhaps you have a lift outside your home, ready for your boat to be perched and lowered. This is a solid Florida boat storage selection, but make sure that if a hurricane or tropical storm looms, you’ve taken the necessary precautions to keep that on-site boat secured.
Marina storage
Storage at a marina is another viable way to keep your boat safe and at the ready for future voyages. Often, marinas will offer security details–but you should still never keep expensive equipment aboard when storing your boat.
For those who don’t live on the water, or who don’t want to keep a boat on their property, a marina can be a wonderful choice. Before you select one, make sure to thoroughly understand their
rules and regulations
, especially how easy (or difficult) it will be to access your craft whenever you’d like.
Dry stack storage
In dry stacking, boats are placed on racks, often indoors and away from the elements. To retrieve your boat, you’ll need to call the storage facility ahead of time and have it lowered and prepared to move safely to your trailer via forklift. This storage option is attractive to those who boat rarely or don’t reside in Florida permanently.
Boatyard storage
Boatyard storage is a hybrid Florida boat storage option that combines dry stack storage with near-marina storage. In this case, the stacked boats are kept outside but not necessarily on the water. This is less expensive than marina storage and keeps you relatively close to an embarkation point. You’ll need to follow the same call-ahead process you’d use when dry docking.
No matter which Florida boat storage mode you select, resist the impulse to keep the vessel in the water for an extended period of time. Salt water is highly corrosive to boats and, for those not in salt water, weather damage can be catastrophic. At the very least, lift the boat out of the water and remove any electronic equipment and valuables after every excursion.
Importance of marine insurance
Florida marine insurance is so absolutely vital. When it comes to everything you need to know to own a boat in this beautiful state, understanding marine insurance ranks near the top of requirements for safe boating.
Marine insurance is the ultimate protection for your vessel. Consider it a sort of ‘invisible life jacket’ you carry with you as you navigate the waterways. Before you ever load the fishing gear and cooler, stock the first aid kit, or chart that first Sunshine State boating excursion, you must protect yourself, your passengers, and your vessel from the unexpected. No one can predict the future–but marine insurance can safeguard you against many unexpected troubles.
Things to consider when purchasing Florida marine insurance
Insurance cost
depends on the type of vessel, the surrounding environment, the contents aboard, and how you’ll use the boat. You will want to consider physical damage coverage and liability while also considering optimal coverages available to you.
Call an experienced advisor
to compile a
personalized policy
, as it is easy to miss a vital part of insurance protection. A marine insurance advisor considers multiple elements before ever suggesting a policy.
If an accident were to occur
, would your passengers’ medical care be covered? Who is liable for those injury-related costs? Your marine insurance advisor can help answer these questions and propose solutions.
Prepare for the worst and hope for the best.
That’s what Florida marine insurance is there for– to protect you and your craft in a worst-case scenario, while allowing you to go on every voyage with the calm that comes from that protection.
Stay Protected with W3 Insurance
Florida marine insurance is the ultimate life jacket. Cover your vessel and those aboard, and set off to explore the Sunshine State’s famous waterways. Stay covered with help from W3 Marine Insurance–and bon voyage! Speak with an experienced marine insurance advisor and
request a quote today
.

Bass Fishing Boat Insurance 101: What Every Angler Needs to Know
10 Most Common Boat Insurance Claims
The Best Storage Options to Protect Your Boat
Preparing Your Boat for a Storm

The Best Storage Options to Protect Your Boat
August 15, 2022								    In
Boat Ownership
Yacht Insurance
Protect your boat from the elements
Searching for the best boat storage options? Keep your vessel shipshape by shielding it from the elements and you’ll reap the longevity benefits that come with a well-maintained marine craft.
Unless you store your vessel indoors in a hurricane-safe storage facility, it’s often difficult to keep it completely safe from the elements.
There are different ways to achieve this aim, and it’s helpful to consider each one before making your ultimate boat storage selection. Reduce wear and tear on your boat by selecting the option that’s right for you.
First, let’s answer the obvious question: Why is it important to properly store your boat? In a perfect world, boats would be impervious to the effects of weather or corrosion. You could park your vessel in the driveway and never worry about a tree falling and damaging onboard contents; it would be just fine to tie up to a dock and keep that hull bobbing in the water indefinitely. This is a world where corrosion exists, unfortunately. The threat of potentially violent weather poses a threat as well. Therefore, it is important to have a plan for securing your boat accordingly. How you do that is up to you, but this guide can help you decide.
So what are your boat storage Florida options? You can store the boat either in-the-water or out, covered or wide open. But there are more options than you might think. What really wins the blue ribbon for ‘the best boat storage option’ depends on the type of boat and the storage options that are actually nearby.
The answer that is right for one Florida boat owner is different from the answer for another. Here are some highlights of different boat storage modes and different boat storage ideas to consider.
Types of boat storage
In-water storage
Caution: extra care necessary.
Let’s start with the easiest storage option available to everyone: in-the-water storage. If you do not care how long your vessel stays pristine, this is a great option. We suggest that you don’t store your boat this way for any length of time. Your boat will be
fully exposed
to water, which can wear away at that shiny gel coat. Should a storm occur, the vessel could also break free of its mooring and float into another person’s backyard waterway. If you absolutely have to leave your boat bobbing in the water, take care to
secure it extremely well
with lines. Hopefully, you have a plan to take it out and secure a different means of storage as soon as possible.
At-home storage
Unless you plan to
use your garage for boat storage only
, this will not work well. Trailering the boat and keeping it on the side of the house may be an option; if you choose to do that, make sure to take all items off the boat every time you park it and have a secure cover.
Lift storage
For those boat owners who use boat lifts, this is a viable means of boat storage. One of the benefits of lift storage is that the boat will be
easy to launch
; this may mean that you and your family will use it more often than you might if the vessel were at an offsite location. It takes mere seconds to lower a boat from its lofty lift perch and into the water. Within a minute or two, you and your family are then off on the next watery excursion.
Keep in mind that when storing your boat on a lift, you must take care to
properly secure it in the event of inclement weather
. A boat that is overrun by storm surge may break free of its tether. The Internet is full of shocking pictures of boats tipped half-in, half-out of the water or nudged into neighboring backyards by strong currents, wind, & tidal surge.
Platform lifts and profile lifts
are two options, and as for cost, a good rule is to expect to pay approximately $1 for every pound that the lift will have to hoist. For the sake of preparedness, this is definitely a time to overestimate your costs.
Outdoor boatyard
An outdoor boatyard is another option. It’s essentially a car lot filled with boats. Covers can be used to offer further protection. Some boatyards are adjacent to marinas, but it will likely cost less to keep your vessel in the nearby boatyard than in the marina itself.
Marina slips
Marinas offer a few options for storing your boat. One option is the
wet slip
, in which a vessel will securely float in the water. Often, this storage area is covered and offers fair protection from the elements. Still, this is a version of that in-water storage that can lead to corrosion of the paint and other wear-and-tear.
Another option is a
lift slip
, which is just what it sounds like. The boat is lifted out of the water, which helps prevent the erosion it can suffer in the water.
However, not every marina covers its lifts, meaning that the elements can affect the vessel. This can cause major problems if a storm hits and the boat is not properly secured.
High-and-dry storage
This indoor option keeps your vessel out of the sun and surf. This is ideal for those who
do not plan to use the boat on a regular basis
. It is necessary to call ahead and have someone remove your vessel from its perch before you can trailer it to the next destination. This adds another step to the preparation you must do before taking the boat out on the water, so consider whether high-and-dry storage is too much of a hassle.
Storage costs
The cost to store a boat
will vary widely
based on the type of storage and the location of the facility. The cheapest mode of storage is obviously at-home storage. The most expensive will likely be at a marina, where you often reap the benefits of on-site security along with a convenient way to launch.
No matter which way you choose to store a boat, it is
important to properly insure it
. Though Florida does not require marine insurance for boat owners, electing not to purchase a policy is a huge risk. Many destruction scenarios can happen that involve a vessel, and accidents and property loss are only two. The best course of action is to
select a marine insurance advisor
you trust to build a personalized policy plan for you.
Explore the water with confidence
W3 Insurance protects vessels so that their owners can feel confident exploring the waterways. Boating is such a joy; protect yourself for the unexpected by trusting W3 Insurance with your boat insurance requirements.
Speak with an experienced W3 marine insurance advisor and
request a quote today
.

Upgrading Your Vessel? Why a Resume of Experience Matters for Yacht Insurance
December 23, 2025								    In
Yacht Insurance
When you are looking to insure pleasure use yachts, the process can sometimes feel complicated. However, one of the most critical factors insurance companies look at isn’t just the boat itself—it’s you. Specifically, underwriters want to understand your history and overall experience as an owner.
In the world of yachting, experience is everything. This is especially true when you decide to purchase a vessel that is significantly different from ones you have owned before. For example, if your yacht owner’s history consists of vessels under 60 feet and you are now buying a 75-foot vessel, this “jump in length” is significant. It might require hiring a full-time captain to navigate the yacht.
Perhaps you are moving from twin-engine fishing boats to a sportfish with quads. This increase in power may cause concern for underwriters, potentially leading to a higher deductible or a “Named Operator Warranty” on the
yacht insurance policy
.
In these scenarios, carriers often require a detailed resume of your experience, including any loss/claim history, before providing an insurance quote. But why is this such a significant factor? Let’s dive in.
Request a Quote for Yacht Insurance
Understanding the “Jump” in Length and Power
For any yacht, the size and the power of its engines can significantly affect both its performance and the boating safety of its operation. The length overall of the yacht and the number of engines it has influence several important aspects.
1. Safety and Stability
A larger yacht usually requires advanced handling techniques because it is less maneuverable than a smaller boat. Similarly, multiple engines provide more power but introduce different handling characteristics, especially in rough waters.
2. Performance Expectations
Larger yachts with more powerful engines travel faster and cover greater distances. However, this comes with increased risk. A jump in length or power changes how the vessel behaves, and without proper experience, a yachter may struggle to control it within their navigation limits.
3. Wear and Tear
Larger yachts undergo greater stresses, which affect durability. Marine insurance providers need to understand this to evaluate risks accurately and adjust premiums or coverage options.
4. Operational Complexity
Managing a yacht
with increased length or multiple engines is far more complex than handling a smaller, single-engine yacht. The operation of additional engines requires a greater understanding of engine synchronization and fuel management, especially in an emergency.
Why Insurance Carriers Need a Resume of Experience Upfront
Providing a boating resume isn’t just paperwork; it’s about securing the right insurance protection for your specific needs.
Comprehensive Risk Assessment
A yacht’s size and power are directly tied to the risks an insurer needs to account for. The larger and more powerful the yacht, the higher the potential for property damage or bodily injury in an accident. By providing a resume upfront, insurance carriers can assess the operator’s experience with the yacht’s specifications to determine if they can handle the associated risks. This proactive risk management approach enables a thorough evaluation from the outset.
Enhanced Accuracy and Efficiency
Submitting a resume upfront ensures that all relevant details about the yacht owner’s experience are available early in the process. This minimizes the risk of discrepancies and provides consistent information. It also streamlines the decision-making process regarding insurance solutions, leading to faster processing times and quicker application approval.
Handling and Maintenance Knowledge
Handling a larger yacht with multiple engines requires specific skills. Whether it’s docking, navigating tight spots, or dealing with rough waters, these skills need to be built up over time. Insurance companies want to ensure that the yacht operator has experience with these nuances. A resume of experience that demonstrates a history of safe operation helps reassure insurers that the yacht is in capable hands.
Moreover,
regular maintenance of larger yachts
is crucial. Insurance carriers want to know that the yacht owner is proactive about maintaining the yacht properly, as this significantly affects the risk of mechanical failure or accidents.
Customized Coverage
With larger yachts or those with more complex systems, a generic policy—or relying on standard homeowners endorsements—will not provide the necessary coverage. A resume of experience helps insurers craft a policy that offers the right
yacht insurance coverage
.
When we look at your experience, we can better structure the policy to address:
Hull Coverage:
Protection for physical damage to your vessel
Agreed Value vs. Actual Cash Value:
Determining whether your policy covers the agreed value (the insured amount decided at the start) or the actual cash value (which factors in depreciation)
Liability Coverage:
Essential protection and indemnity (P&I) for third-party liabilities, including bodily injury and property damage
Medical Payments:
Coverage for necessary medical expenses for you or your passengers
Uninsured Boater:
Protection if you are hit by someone who lacks proper coverage
Personal Property and Personal Effects:
Protecting your belongings on board, separate from the vessel itself
Wreck Removal:
Covering the cost to remove your vessel if it sinks or blocks a waterway
Jones Act:
Coverage for crew members
if you employ a captain or crew
Lay-up:
Defining periods when the boat is out of commission, which can affect premiums
Understanding these coverage options helps you answer the question, “What kind of insurance do you need for a yacht?” versus a smaller boat.
Request a Quote for Yacht Insurance
Yachtsman Education and Experience
Yachtsman education, certifications such as Merchant Marine, Captains License, USCG Auxiliary, or United States Power Squadron courses, and hands-on experience play a vital role in how an insurer assesses risk. Underwriters prefer operators with a proven track record. By detailing your certifications and boating courses, you can improve your chances of receiving comprehensive insurance solutions at the most competitive terms and premiums.
Demonstrating a commitment to boating safety and continuous learning—such as staying up to date on navigation limits and new technologies—builds trust. This transparency can positively influence the terms of your policy, offering you greater peace of mind.
Building Trust and Credibility
Providing a resume upfront demonstrates transparency and a willingness to share comprehensive information. This builds trust with the underwriters and shows that the yacht owner is serious about the application process. It reassures insurance carriers that the owner is committed to safe and knowledgeable yachting practices, which can positively influence the terms and conditions of the insurance policy.
Additional Considerations for Yacht Owners
The Role of Technology in Modern Yachting
Modern yachts are equipped with advanced technology that can enhance safety and performance, but also add to the complexity of operation. A detailed resume of experience should highlight any training or experience the yacht owner has with these technologies. This can further reassure insurance carriers that the owner is well-prepared to handle the sophisticated systems onboard.
Environmental Considerations
Larger yachts and those with multiple engines can have a greater environmental impact. Responsible yacht ownership includes understanding and mitigating this impact. Demonstrating a commitment to environmental stewardship can be a positive factor when seeking insurance coverage.
The Importance of Continuous Learning
The world of yachting is constantly evolving. Continuous learning is essential for staying up to date and ensuring safe, responsible yacht operation. Including a history of continuous learning on your resume of experience can demonstrate to insurers that you are committed to maintaining and enhancing your skills over time.
The Role of Professional Networks
Being part of professional yachting networks or associations can provide yacht owners with valuable support and resources. These networks often offer access to training, industry news, and best practices. They can also provide a platform for sharing experiences and learning from other yacht owners. Mentioning your involvement in professional networks or associations on your resume can further bolster your credibility with insurance carriers.
Securing Your Investment and Peace of Mind
A jump in size and/or number of engines in some instances can impact your insurability. Insurance carriers rely on a detailed resume of experience to assess whether the yacht is being operated by an insured or by a captain accustomed to navigating similar vessels. Additionally, the cost of ownership and maintenance of the yacht has become more complex and more expensive.
Whether you are purchasing a new yacht with significant differences in size and engine capacity from your prior yachting experience, providing a comprehensive resume of your experience upfront is essential.
Ensuring that your resume includes detailed information about your yachting history, education, certifications, and relevant occupational skills can significantly enhance your chances of obtaining the best possible boat insurance or
yacht insurance coverage
. This proactive approach not only protects your investment against partial losses or replacement costs but also contributes to a safer, more enjoyable yachting experience.
The resume of experience is not just a formality but a crucial document that reflects your capability and commitment as a yacht owner. It serves as a testament to your skills, knowledge, and dedication to safe yachting practices. By providing a detailed, comprehensive resume of your experience upfront, you can build confidence with insurance carriers, ensuring you receive the liability insurance and physical damage coverage you need to protect your valuable asset and enjoy the full benefits of yacht ownership.
FAQs About Yacht Insurance
What Factors Affect the Cost of Yacht Insurance?
Several factors influence your premium, including the vessel’s value, size, age, cruising area (navigation limits), your boating resume, and the deductible you choose.
What is a Normal Deductible?
A deductible is the amount you pay out of pocket before insurance covers the rest. For yachts, this is typically a percentage of the insured value (often 1% to 2%). An increased Named Storm Deductible is also applicable to most yacht policies. Note that in the event of a total loss, the deductible application may vary based on your specific policy terms.
Do I Need Yacht Insurance for International Waters?
Standard boat insurance usually has specific territorial limits. If you plan to travel internationally, you must inform your broker to ensure your yacht insurance coverage extends to those regions.
What Are the Exclusions from Yacht Insurance Policies?
Standard exclusions include wear and tear, gradual deterioration, osmosis, and damage caused by lack of maintenance. Indemnity is generally intended for sudden, accidental losses, not for maintenance issues.
Ready to upgrade your vessel? Contact a W3 Marine Insurance Advisor today to secure coverage for your new yacht.
