Offshore Rising Stars Ellie Driver & Ollie Hill: Young Short-Hand Ambition and Success
Rising stars of solo offshore sailing – Ellie Driver and Ollie Hill – are taking on some of short-handed racing’s toughest tests in the Figaro fleet. Georgie Corlett-Pitt tells their story.
Author
:
Georgie Corlett-Pitt
Published Date:
2 December 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Ellie Driver & Ollie Hill sailing in the Figaro  |  Photo credit: Vincent Olivaud
Just a few seasons ago, Ellie Driver burst onto the offshore scene racing two-up with her dad, Jim Driver, onboard their Sun Fast 3300,
Chilli Pepper
– a move that was, in equal measures, bold and inspiring. For sure, taking on some of the UK’s top offshore events two-up and while still in her teens marked a significant step-up for Ellie – her previous sailing had begun in Optimists at Trearddur Bay SC and taken her on to compete internationally with the 420 British Team. But when Covid forcibly halted that campaign, about the only way to keep racing was double-handed offshore, and while sailing with her dad may have seemed a little unusual, Ellie says, they have always got on well and “it made perfect sense at the time”.
Ellie Driver and Jim Driver
Now, 2025 has brought another big step for 23-year old Ellie. A new campaign in the foiling one-design Beneteau Figaro 3 has already seen her take on one of the toughest solo offshore races,
La Solitaire du Figaro Paprec
. Completing it was, she says, “a dream come true”, and a major tick towards her ultimate goal of the 2032 Vendée Globe.
When we speak, Ellie has just returned from competing in the Rolex Middle Sea Race – a 600nm sprint from Malta around Sicily – on board Gordon Ketelbey’s fully-crewed TP52
Zen
. While Ellie recounts the race’s most memorable moments – from the dramatic start line within Valletta’s Grand Harbour, to sailing past Stromboli as it spewed clouds of ash – the sailing itself she says made a complete contrast to the short-handed racing she is accustomed to, with “plenty of corners and opportunities to learn, as well as a lot less personal space and a lot more sleep”.
Short-Handed Sailing
More used to handling the boat entirely by herself and napping for mere minutes at a time, this season Ellie has clocked up some 7,300nm of short-handed sailing, including her first transat.
Ellie on her first  single-handed race,  the brutal La Solitaire  |  Photo credit: T Campion
Undoubtedly, short-handed sailing is where her passion lies. She attributes much of that to her dad, himself an accomplished offshore racer, who spent many years racing for the Army sailing team, and who Ellie describes as having “endless energy and drive”. She recalls childhood days sailing a Mirror with her dad, before progressing to squads. So when Jim suggested they give double-handed keelboat racing a try, Ellie jumped at the idea, though, she says, not without a little trepidation at racing bigger boats.
The twist came in the timing – and in Ellie’s eagerness to make the most of any opportunity.
In 2020 Ellie took up a place at Southampton University studying Maritime Engineering. Instead of languishing in her room during the pandemic lockdowns, she threw herself into RORC’s race scene – skeletal that year through necessity and comprising mostly short-handed events – and discovered a welcoming community embracing the burgeoning double-handed scene. At the time, the discipline was also under consideration for the
Olympics
.
Taking part in their first offshore double-handed race later that year, Ellie and her dad were pleased to find themselves ahead of Shirley Robertson and Jeremy Waitt on JPK1010
Jangada
. That was until a radio call from Shirley informed them they’d missed a mark and needed to double-back several miles to correct their mistake. It was a classic rookie error, but nonetheless Ellie appreciated the inclusive approach, saying: “It was a good environment to be in as it let you push yourself harder.”
A Tough Offshore Test
Perhaps the ultimate test for Ellie and Jim came in taking on RORC’s Sevenstar Round Britain and Ireland Race – an arduous 1,800nm circumnavigation that took them exactly two full weeks to complete. This time, they finished just ahead of Shirley who was sailing two-up with Dee Caffari. Impressively, Ellie became the youngest skipper to complete the race, and one of only five female sailors to ever do so double-handed. It was a real testament to her determination in overcoming any doubts that the wider sailing community may have cast over her age, gender or ability, and an achievement that earned her Sailor of the Year at STY&Y’s British Yachting Awards later that year.
It was about that time that Ellie had applied for
The Magenta Project’s mentoring scheme
. She explains how a conversation with her mentor, Annie O’Sullivan, a skipper with The Maiden Factor, had encouraged her to vocalise her Vendée Globe ambitions for the first time, and crucially, Annie’s positive response had given her the confidence to pursue it.
It made Ellie’s foray into the Figaro class the following year all the more important, and she was delighted to win at the EUROSAF Double-Handed Female European Offshore Championships with Catherine Hunt, and place second in the Mixed Double-Handed Worlds with George Kennedy. She also clocked up another Fastnet Race with her dad on
Chilli Pepper
, this time finishing 10th double-hander and second female skipper and second youth skipper overall.
By now, Ellie and Jim had sailed every event they could together, and the time came to graduate from their dad-daughter duo. She smiles as she acknowledges her own highly competitive nature, saying: “We learned a huge amount together and had a lot of fun, but felt like it was naturally time to move on.”
There was just one thing stopping her from her next step: “I had promised my parents I would graduate uni before becoming a pro sailor, so I decided I should probably do my exams rather than sail across the Atlantic!”
While Ellie paused her sailing to complete her Masters degree, in the meantime, dad Jim had been turning his attention to developing the RORC Griffin programme, encouraging young sailors into offshore racing and creating opportunities to hone skills and gain experience that will ultimately bolster the UK yacht racing scene. With hundreds of young people already benefitting over the first few years of the scheme, Ellie is full of praise for her dad’s involvement and the impact that it is having.
Ambitions Aligned: Ellie Driver & Ollie Hill
For Ellie, the moment she graduated she set her sights on her next challenge – the Transat Paprec; acquiring her own Figaro – named for her inspirational partnership with the support charity, Women’s Engineering Society – and teaming up with co-skipper, Ollie Hill for this unique double-handed/mixed-gender event.
Ollie and Ellie  |  Photo credit: Figaro
Ollie joins our chat also freshly returned from completing the Middle Sea Race on Simon Toms’ SunFast 3300,
Zephyr
– notably having won IRC6 and 10th overall on IRC. The affable 25-year old explains that, after graduating in Yacht Design from Southampton Solent, he was inspired to step into the Figaro fleet by Nigel King, Volvo Ocean Race sailor and coach to Shirley and Dee’s two-handed campaign, with whom he had worked on several pro sailing campaigns.
While Ollie’s ambitions stop short of his own Vendée Globe campaign, his focus is firmly on winning La Solitaire du Figaro, a goal that stands as an achievement in its own right. The class, he says, “offers very pure racing and creates incredibly talented sailors in a remarkably short time”, noting that not only does the fleet feed many top-level sailors into Class40 and IMOCA campaigns, but it retains a very high calibre of sailors, and as such, the class is notoriously difficult to dominate. He points to Alexis Loison’s win of this year’s La Solitaire on the 19th attempt, showing an inspiring combination of talent and tenacity. Ollie’s own extensive experience shows similar qualities: as a 17-year old, he set a world record for sailing around the Isle of Wight in 11.5 hours – in an Optimist! Later, after competing at international level with the British squads, he went on to race in IRC and SB20s in the Middle East, then taking on the
ARC
, and racing on the Caribbean circuit before a return to the UK for university, which launched him into the RORC racing scene at the front of Cape 31 and IRC fleets. Making his mark in short-handed sailing, he won the opening leg of the IRC Double-Handed Euros in 2024 with Josh Dawson.
After realising their ambitions were closely aligned, in early 2025, Ellie and Ollie relocated to
Brittany
, the epicentre of offshore racing. A brave decision for the young couple but one that gained them an invitation to join the Lorient Grand Large academy. Offering an intense programme for solo sailors focussing on nav, weather routing and endurance sailing skills, the academy provides a level of training that’s been noticeably absent in the UK since the demise of the Artemis Offshore Academy, nearly a decade ago. While schemes like the Griffin Project are now working to redress that skills gap on home waters, the move to France meant Ollie and Ellie could fast-track their learning.
Ellie Driver & Ollie Hill
There, they have found appeal in the focused and professional approach to campaigning, and were delighted by the ready acceptance they’ve been offered as serious contenders – despite the language barrier! – as Ollie describes: “Everyone is there to help each other. There’s a strong sense of camaraderie because everyone knows how tough this kind of sailing is.”
Ellie says the training has sharpened her self-taught approach and pushed her sailing to a higher standard.
Taking on the Figaro: A Learning Experience
The first chance for the duo to test their newly acquired Figaro skills came in April last year year, with the double-handed Transat Paprec – a 3,890nm race which took them 19 days, racing from Concarneau in Brittany to St Barths in the Caribbean, via a mark in the Canaries.
Their sense of achievement in completing such a marathon was overwhelming. Ellie describes it as an “adventure” in which they faced everything, from autopilot failure to winds of 60kts – but says that above all it was “a great eye-opener as to areas we could improve”.
Relief at the finish of the 3890nm Transat  |  Photo credit: Vincent Olivaud
Immediately after returning to Europe, they began preparing for the 1,850nm single-handed multi-stage race, La Solitaire du Figaro Paprec, from Rouen on the northern French coast, to Vigo, Spain and back to Normandy. Ollie – having only initially set out to do the double-handed Transat – decided to continue training, digging into savings to charter his own Figaro,
Connected by Water
.
Start day arrived, and having done only one solo race previously– over just two days and in light airs – Ellie and Ollie set off from Rouen, each determined to give La Solitaire their best shot; the two Brits among only five non-French sailors in the 35-strong fleet.
With three, five-day legs and as little as 24 hours onshore in between, both agree the experience was compelling yet exhausting: from dodging the tail end of an Atlantic storm and criss-crossing the Channel’s busy shipping lanes multiple times, to battling the wilds of Biscay then floundering in zero wind.
“With a fleet of 35 identical boats racing in such close quarters, Figaro racing is almost like dinghy racing – it’s impossible to relax,” explains Ollie, who says by leg three they were both feeling the effects of cumulative sleep deprivation. Although they had support from a préparateur on shore, as well as parents and friends handling logistics, the very short stopovers made for little respite. “You start to question your decisions,” says Ollie. “That was, mentally and physically, the most taxing leg. But it’s incredible what your body can do without sleep for so many days in horrendous circumstances, even if, at the time, you are running on adrenaline – and the stress of such a compressed fleet. However, by the end everyone completely crashed!”
Placing 19th overall and 5th Rookie Ollie was also the first non-French finisher and was duly awarded the coveted Vivi Trophy. It was an outstanding result, particularly given the short preparation period, but Ollie is quick to emphasise that it illustrates how the Figaro class, while open to newcomers, demands high standards of professionalism.
In at the Deep End
For Ellie, embarking on her first full-on solo race brought a sense of “in at the deep end”.
“It was great fun, but also a huge mental and physical challenge,” she says. “Pretty quickly, I realised the enormity of what I had taken on. The biggest challenge came in the last-minute change of course on the first leg due to the weather, which threw up a lot of unknowns. But once I had completed leg one, it gave me confidence to go on and complete the next two. The race was brutal, and looking back, I’m incredibly proud of what I’ve achieved.”
Ellie Driver and Ollie Hill - 2025 has been an incredible  season for these two  ambitious sailors  |  Photo credit: Vincent Olivaud
When I ask if they’d take on La Solitaire again, it’s a resounding “yes” from both.
While Ollie sums it up as a “hidden gem of a race – relentless, gruesome, but one that brings out brilliant sailors”, Ellie explains that their search for partners to enable them to continue their campaigns is already well underway. “It’s an ongoing battle,” she says. “Do you spend your time trying to get more partners, or do you go out training and improve your sailing? Realistically, both are as important as each other.”
It’s hard not to sense a little frustration, naturally, but nonetheless, there’s excitement there too, as they both acknowledge that success comes as much from putting in the hard yards on shore as it does from churning up the miles offshore. And if the competitive yet grounded determination they both have shown so far are anything to go by, then there’s no doubt these two will be ones to back when it comes to Britain’s future success in offshore racing.

Sailing in Corsica, Sardinia & Sicily: Mediterranean Chartering
These captivating Med islands, offering distinct landscapes, rich cultures, and excellent charter cruising opportunities writes Sue Pelling.
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
27 March 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Panorama of Harbour and old houses in Cefalu in Sicily, Italy in a beautiful summer day. Credit: iStock
Exploring Mediterranean chartering? Corsica, Sardinia, and Sicily are three of the most captivating islands in the Mediterranean, each offering distinct landscapes, rich cultures, and excellent cruising opportunities for a charter holiday writes Sue Pelling.
Corsica is known for its dramatic mountainous terrain and rugged coastline, offering a blend of natural beauty and cultural heritage. Its proximity to Sardinia (just 9nm apart) makes it an ideal starting point for a cruising adventure in the western Mediterranean. Corsica is a blend of French and Italian influences, with charming coastal villages, crystal-clear waters, and stunning beaches. The island’s interior is a haven for hikers and nature lovers, with deep gorges, lush forests, and towering peaks like Monte Cinto.
Sardinia, the second-largest island in the Mediterranean, is famous for its beautiful beaches, ancient ruins, and wild, rugged landscapes. The island has a rich history dating back to the Phoenicians, Romans, and even earlier, with numerous archaeological sites scattered throughout. Sardinia is also renowned for its excellent sailing conditions, offering sheltered bays, dramatic cliffs, and idyllic islands like La Maddalena Archipelago. With Corsica so close, Sardinia also benefits from a similar Mediterranean charm but with a distinct Italian flavour.
Old Sardinian Port with ships at Mediterranean Sea and city of Cagliari, South Sardinia Island in Italy in summer. Cityscape with marina and Yachts and boats in town
Sicily, the largest island in the Mediterranean, located just off the southern tip of Italy, takes in three sea areas (Mediterranean, Tyrrhenian, and Ionian). It is therefore a land of ancient history, dramatic landscapes, and a vibrant mix of cultures. Its location however, means the northwest winds can be strong sometimes reaching 25+kts, so it’s a great place if you want to expand your sailing skill. An exciting aspect of cruising in this region is the visibility of active volcanoes like Mount Etna and Stromboli. Watching the eruptions from the deck of your yacht, especially at night, can be a mesmerizing experience. Stromboli, in particular, is one of the most active volcanoes in the world, providing a dynamic and ever-changing landscape if you want to explore the Aeolian Islands.
The relatively short distances between these islands – especially Corsica and Sardinia – make for easy and scenic cruising. Although the waters around these islands are typically calm and clear, and ideal for yacht charters, there are some areas in places like the Strait of Bonifacio between north Sardinia and Corsica, the Aeolian Islands, and in the Strait of Messina between Sicily and the mainland that are known for big winds, so always check with your charter agent who should be able to offer more detailed advice on conditions.
Aerial view showcasing its historic architecture, stunning coastline, and Mediterranean charm of Cefalu, Sicily.
There are numerous yacht charter companies and agents covering this particular area, with companies like
Dream Yacht Worldwide
,
Nautilus Yachting
,
Plain Sailing
, and
Seafarer Sailing
offering charters in all three. If you are interested in a flotilla holiday in this area, Tubber is well worth investigating because this company has a selection of package routes in all areas. On the Sardinia flotilla you can discover the dazzling Costa Smeralda and Maddalena archipelago starting from the base in Cannigione, Sardinia, all the way to Corsica. The company’s week long flotilla in Sicily gives you the opportunity to explore Portorosa and the surrounding area, and sailing from one volcanic island to another in company.
Sailing Holidays offers a two-week charter holiday sailing around Sardinia and Corsica starting from Portiisco (Sardinia), just a short journey from Olbia Costa Smeralda Airport. As with all its charters, Sailing Holiday offers a comprehensive itinerary and useful sailing guide to ensure you get the best from your holiday.
Sunsail
offers charter in Sicily from its Portorosa base, as well as the Aeolian Islands. This company also has a base for bareboat or skippered charter in Sardinia on a Sun Odyssey 319 from Cannigione into the Gulf of Arzachena. This cruise, with its fun-packed, yet cultural itinerary will ensure you see the best of what Sardinia and its glamorous coastline has to offer including recommended lunch stops at places like Cala Corlotto to the west of La Maddalena where you can anchor, sunbathe and swim in the most beautiful crystal clear water.
Girolata Bay in Corsica, Corse-du-Sud, France. Girolata is located in the Scandola Nature Reserve. It can not be reached by car, only by walking or by boat.
If you are looking for a by-the-cabin charter, which is an ideal way to holiday if you are travelling solo, or are totally new to sailing/want to gain experience under the supervision of experienced crew members, then Sailsquare could be a good choice. This company has a huge range of options on a selection of different monohulls and multihulls, and what’s included in the price is clearly explained on its website.
For bareboat charter in particular, there are plenty of independent yacht charter agents who cover the area including samboat, the globesailor and
Anchor.yt
. Most of the websites are extremely informative and some even offer an option to sign up a skipper. The globesailor is a good example of yacht charter agent that also offers a by-the-cabin charter package.
As with all sailing holidays where ‘complete packages’ are advertised, ensure you check what’s actually included because most companies don’t, for example, include flights or transfers. And when you are in a shared yacht situation such as by-the-cabin, there will more than likely be extra funds required (often fixed rate) to cover food and drink onboard, fuel, mooring fees and other costs.

Yachts for Sale: Three of the Best Sailing Boats on the Market
Here’s our top picks from the yacht market - some beautiful sailing boats ready for their next chapter.
Author
:
Sailing Today
Published Date:
24 November 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
yachts for sale  |  Photo credit: Alex Grabu
RUSTLER 44 |  SEA HAYES
Designed by Stephen Jones to produce a swift, comfortable passage, and built by Rustler Yachts for stunning, durable living, this is an ultimate bluewater cruising yacht. She has recently returned to the UK following a season in the Caribbean, and is a fine example offered in ready to sail condition with many features including a generator, inverter, heating, bow thruster, electric halyard winch, and electric primary winches.
Sea Hayes
also has a comprehensive electronics package, davits, white sails (2020), cruising chute, recent batteries, recent standing rigging, dinghy and outboard, and much more. She is in very good condition and is currently located outside the Rustler factory in Falmouth.

Yachts for Sale: Catamaran
GUNBOAT 48 | DANCING BEAR
Dancing Bear
is an extremely rare to the market Morrelli & Melvin-designed carbonfibre Gunboat 48 with upgraded rig and interior. She has had just one private owner since new and is now offered for sale with a great performance-cruising inventory. She has been finished to a high standard including a new interior by Riskas Snickeri (Nautor Swan & Baltic Yachts) which the broker reports costing circa €600,000 in 2013. She also has many inventory highlights including 3-cabin, 3-heads interior layout with a sumptuous owner’s cabin aft, and VIP cabins forward. Her windows and all glass were renewed in 2019 and, in 2010 she had a new rig and taller wing-mast fitted by Marström, as well as new ECSix standing rigging in 2022. Her sail wardrobe comprises, Harken low-friction battencars for fully-battened mainsail, North 3Di mainsail and jibs (2011), One Sails mainsail and J2 (2023), new unused code zero from North Sails, plus a furling code zero and spinnakers. Navigation wise,
Dancing Bear
is fully equipped for serious cruising including a B&G navigation system with plotter, HD radar, AIS and night-vision top-mast camera, as well as twin autopilot systems.

MOODY DS 41 |  VENTURA
Ventura
is the first of the sought-after Moody DS 41s to come up for sale in the UK and is a very good, highly specified example with only 155 hours on the clock. She was launched and commissioned for the 2022 season and the brokers report that she is ‘nicely presented for sale’. This particular Moody – also known as the Moody 41 DS and Moody Deck saloon 41 – is the shallow draft keel version, and has plenty of features including twin forestay upgrade, electric winches, full Raymarine navigation suite, heating system, electric loo and more. She has a Selden rig with an electric in-mast furling system, furlex inner forestay (manual), furlex outer forestay (electric), manual backstay adjuster, and a rodkicker/vang. Her sail wardrobe comprises Elvstrom bluewater dacron in-mast furling mainsail, self-tacking jib, and 140% genoa.

Tales from the Clipper Race 2025: JT’s Journey to the Equator
Since late August, the crews of the Clipper Race 2025-26 have been hurtling around the globe, pushing their boats and themselves to their limits. Jorden Lacey (JT), a Marlow Ropes Ambassador and member of the crew onboard Team Warrant, has been documenting the highs and lows of life at sea, as he takes on this 40,000 nautical mile, six-ocean circumnavigation.
Author
:
Milly Karsten
Published Date:
6 October 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Warrent - Clipper Race 2025  |  Photo credit: Marlow Ropes
After stepping away from over 15 years in finance, and drawing on previous sailing experience, JT has partnered up with the official running rigging supplier,
Marlow Ropes
, taking on the role of supporting the Bosun with rigging and repairs on board their Clipper boat. Here’s JT’s updates from the last month or so at sea.
JT on Warrant  |  Photo credit: Jorden Lacey
Race 1, Leg 1
On 31st August 2025, the
Clipper fleet departed Portsmouth
, toward Puerto Sherry, Spain. From the outset, the crew faced headwinds and challenging seas in the Bay of Biscay, pushing them to stay vigilant and adapt their tactics.
JT told Marlow - “The Battle over Biscay in this Race Edition was undeniably tough for everyone. In that period we encountered not one, but three depressions coming through the North Atlantic, and what could have been a shorter and more comfortable downwind trip became a much more challenging, and tactical, upwind beat for most of the time.”
Arriving in Puerto Sherry, the team took 4 days to make repairs, deep clean and restock, ready for the next stage.
Race 2, Leg 1
Taking the Clipper fleet 5,300 NM across the Atlantic to Uruguay, Race 2 marked the first true ocean crossing.
In the first couple of days, JT told Marlow, “a few too many heavy collapses and fill ins will flog the kite. Eventually something will give and it’s unlikely to be the sheets from Marlow which have individual breaking strength of up to 10 tons”
“Inevitably, an over-zealous push for speed saw our Code 1 blow, with a sizeable rip. It has been recovered and we will work on a repair when we enter our Doldrums corridor.”
Warrant - Clipper Race  |  Photo credit: Jorden Lacey
On a particularly strenuous night, where physical and mental energy was sapping quickly, the team encountered another challenge - a shoal of flying fish. With over 20 ending up on board and one down below, the crew were spun into a frantic race to remove them.
After a string of bad lunch on day 2, JT told Marlow, they went through “a Code 3 drop and lace, a Yankee 1 hoist, a Code 2 hoist, a Yankee 1 drop, a blown Code 2 donut tack strop (not the dyneema, but the whipping), a Code 2 drop and lace, a Code 2 re-hoist … all within 2 hours … and finally topped off with a Code 2 wrap and drop with an untwisting and lacing exercise on deck as the sun went down!”
Making ground towards the islands of Cape Verde, the crew began to struggle with the sun on deck and conditions down below, bringing on sleep deprivation.
As they headed towards the Doldrums, weighing up when to utilise their motor (60 hours of which is allowed in the race instructions to minimise risk of being stranded and impacting the race schedules downstream), the team held off for as long as possible, using the remaining wind to the final moment.
“The Doldrums hasn’t really been what we expected”, JT told Marlow. Though uncomfortably hot with periods of calm, the team found a fair amount of wind, giving them time to make repairs, and clean both the boat and themselves, while also pushing on.
As we await JT’s next update, on the race tracker we can see that Team Warrant have now crossed the Equator and have reached the coast of Brazil.
Stay tuned for more...!
Show Me More:
New Boats: Fresh Designs on the Yacht Market

What Is the Secret to Sunsail’s Success?
Sam Jefferson caught up with Sunsail’s Clive Norton to find out this charter industry global leader’s secrets of success.
Author
:
Sam Jefferson
Published Date:
5 August 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Croatia – a popular Sunsail destination  |  Photo credit: Sunsail
Sunsail is a charter industry global leader and has plenty to celebrate. Sam Jefferson caught up with Sunsail’s Clive Norton to find out the company’s secrets of success
.
Last year, Sunsail celebrated an incredible milestone – its 50th anniversary. A half-century of helping adventure-lovers explore the world from the deck of an award-winning yacht is no mean feat. Such an achievement can only be accredited to the consistent vision that has guided the company over the decades, with each generation of leadership united by a clear goal – to deliver unforgettable sailing experiences for the sailing community and beyond. To mark the occasion, we caught up with Clive Norton, VP of Revenue Management and Fleet Planning at Sunsail, to reflect on the company’s roots, discussing the journey from launching a small fleet in the Saronic Gulf to becoming a world leading sailing holiday company. In this exclusive interview, we delve into Sunsail’s origins, its milestones and where it is heading next.
Sunsail Vounaki Greece May 2010
Tell us about the history of Sunsail. How did it all begin?
“Sunsail was founded in 1974 and began with the simple ambition to make sailing fun, accessible, and social for everyone. Our very first base was in Aegina, in the stunning Saronic Gulf of Greece, which we still sail from today. We started with just seven 25ft Snapdragon monohulls in the first flotilla. They were sturdy yachts known for their twin bilge keels, shallow draft and spacious interiors – perfect for exploring coastal waters, with ample space in the galley to cater for a family while offering relative comfort. It was a modest start, but one rooted in a deep passion for the sea.
“The team back then was small but mighty. Skipper Janet Green led the first voyages with her Australian hostie, Megan, and English engineer David Archer. Unfortunately, we don’t know much about their history before Sunsail, but we do know that Janet’s role was particularly groundbreaking for the time. In 1974, it was quite rare – and often challenging – for a woman to hold a lead skipper position in the sailing world, which was then overwhelmingly male-dominated. Janet’s leadership not only showcased her exceptional skills and determination but also set an early example of inclusivity and progressiveness that Sunsail continues to embody today.
“This spirit of representation and breaking boundaries set by Janet and the team has continued to shape decision-making within the business. It’s no coincidence that Dee Caffari is one of Sunsail’s contemporary ambassadors. Dee made history as the first woman to sail solo, non-stop, around the world in both directions, and she remains one of the most respected figures in the sport. Her achievements resonate deeply with the values set by the founding team.
“Needless to say, the first ever flotilla trip was a great success, reaching beyond the expectations of the team, and went on to create the first market for holiday flotillas.”
How has Sunsail evolved over the years?
“Over the last five decades, we’ve come a long way. From those first flotilla holidays in Greece, we expanded across the Mediterranean, then into the Caribbean, and now offer bareboat charters in over 20 of the world’s most spectacular sailing destinations. Our flotilla sailing holidays now run in three countries, and our fleet has grown from seven Snapdragons to over 340 yachts.
“Throughout our journey, we’ve worked closely with iconic yacht manufacturers like Beneteau, Jeanneau, and Robertson & Caine to ensure our boats balance performance, comfort and sociability for our guests. Since the first flotilla in 1974 we have steadily invested in the fleet. By the late 1980s we had already added 120 new yachts to the Mediterranean. In 1993, we were operating 390 yachts across the Mediterranean and 100 in the Caribbean. In 2002, we placed a landmark £13 million order for 180 new yachts from Jeanneau, Beneteau, Fountaine Pajot, and Lagoon, further strengthening our global offering.
“Fleet renewal and expansion continued into the 2010s, with major additions from Robertson & Caine’s catamaran range and upgrades to our monohull fleet to match evolving guest expectations. In 2016, we introduced the Sunsail 454 – a custom-built catamaran designed specifically for the charter market. In 2020, we launched the Sunsail 41.0, a sleek, modern yacht created in collaboration with Jeanneau. Most recently, in 2023 and 2024, we continued our fleet growth through a partnership with Dufour, investing in models such as the Sunsail 37.3 and Sunsail 41.3., reflecting our growing focus on sustainability and innovation. Each phase of fleet growth has furthered our commitment to staying ahead of industry trends and delivering exceptional sailing experiences for every type of sailor.
“As we have grown the fleet, we have also deepened our offering to our community, which has seen our team pioneering experiences that accompany sailors through their entire journey. In 1986, we launched our first Beach Club to offer beginner-friendly holiday packages combining land and water-based activities. This marked the beginning of a series of Beach Clubs that followed across the Mediterranean and beyond. This period of time marked the opening of a new space in the market, where sailing enthusiasts could not only enjoy a holiday, but also earn their first sailing qualifications.
“By the mid-2010s our strategy evolved and moved towards a direction more closely reflecting the business we operate today – focusing on accessibility through our
RYA
-accredited Sailing Schools. From there, guests could progress to flotillas and eventually set off on their own bareboat adventures.”
What do you think has been the secret behind Sunsail’s success?
“Honestly, it’s that Sunsail has always been run by sailors, for sailors. We understand what makes a sailing holiday special because we live and breathe it ourselves. Our goal has never changed – we want to make sailing fun, inclusive, and accessible to all.
“And we’re passionate – deeply passionate – about what we do, and how we do it. That enthusiasm translates into everything from how we design our itineraries to how our teams interact with guests. It’s about creating unforgettable experiences and lifelong memories on the water.”
Sunsail Vounaki Greece May 2010
What are some of the most memorable highlights over the last 50 years?
“There are so many. Launching our Caribbean bases was a big step, bringing the Sunsail experience to turquoise waters and island cultures. Another huge moment was expanding our fleet beyond the Mediterranean and adding yachts from world-renowned manufacturers.
“But I think the most rewarding moments are the ones we hear from our guests – families who return year after year, couples who met on a flotilla and now bring their children back, or sailors who took their first lessons with us and are now skippering charters around the world. Those personal stories are what really define our legacy.”
What makes Sunsail unique today?
“Today, our guests have more choice than ever before. Looking for a self-guided adventure? Our bareboat charters offer the freedom to explore at your own pace – and in some locations, we’re even introducing off-grid itineraries for a more remote experience. Prefer a little more structure and camaraderie? Our flotillas provide a sociable and supportive way to sail, with the added reassurance of a lead crew always close by. And if you’re new to sailing, no problem – our RYA-accredited sailing schools are designed to help you learn while on holiday.
“We’ve hand-picked our destinations for their beauty and variety in sailing conditions – from the gentle breezes of the Ionian to the steady trade winds of the British Virgin Islands. It’s all about catering to every level of sailor, from complete beginners to seasoned skippers.
At the heart of our business, we’ve stayed true to our core values – particularly when it comes to customer service. From the very first call, guests are supported by expert holiday planners, who have sailed in the waters they’re recommending. This is a deliberate choice – we want our guests to feel confident knowing they’re speaking to someone with real, first-hand knowledge. That personalised service continues throughout the holiday experience, thanks to our base managers and local lead crews, who have the local insight and ability to make every guest feel supported and welcome.”
What do the next 50 years hold for Sunsail?
“The next 50 years are all about sustainability and innovation. We’re standing on the brink of real change in the yachting world – in how hulls are built, how boats are powered, and how we protect marine ecosystems. We want to lead that charge.
“Through our charitable partners and award-winning internal sustainability initiatives, we’re already laying the groundwork. We’re also exploring how to work more responsibly with local communities in every destination we operate.
“From a design perspective, we’ll continue to collaborate with top manufacturers to stay at the forefront of yacht innovation. Listening to our guests is key – they help us find that sweet spot where comfort, performance and sociability meet.”
Sunsail’s journey from a humble flotilla in the Saronic Gulf to a global sailing holiday pioneer is more than a business success story – it’s a celebration to a vision dedicated to a genuine love for life on the water.
Speaking with Clive, it’s clear that while the fleet, destinations, and technology have evolved, Sunsail’s core purpose has not wavered. As the brand looks ahead to the next 50 years, one thing is certain – the spirit that launched seven Snapdragons in 1974 still guides every voyage today.

Leopard 46 Boat Test: How to Cruise in Comfort
Sam Jefferson takes a big cat from South Africa out for a spin and discovers a beast that has been thoroughly tamed.
Author
:
Sam Jefferson
Published Date:
6 January 2026
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Leopard 46
William Shakespeare is generally noted for being a bit of a sage. Personally I have always thought his comedies lacked a bit of oomph but it must be admitted that he had a great knack of coming up with a pithy line. Anyway, the one that comes to mind when I think of Robertson and Caine, builder of
Leopard Catamarans
, is the following:
There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which taken at the flood, leads on to fortune. Omitted, all the voyage of their life is bound in shallows and in miseries. On such a full sea are we now afloat. And we must take the current when it serves, or lose our ventures.
This may seem somewhat obscure but let me elaborate. At present, Leopard is the third biggest manufacturer of multihulls in the world and the largest in the southern hemisphere. How did this happen? Well, for one, I’m sure it has always built excellent boats but, up until the late ’90s it was producing relatively modest numbers of quite sporty boats (anyone remember the Fast 42?). All well and good, but there are many excellent boatbuilders who don’t go on to grow exponentially. The pivot point in Robertson and Caine’s growth appeared when the manufacturer came to the attention of the Moorings charter group that asked the company to build a line of catamarans that would dovetail with the demands of their charter clients. One thing led to another and Robertson and Caine’s Leopard Catamarans are now ubiquitous not just in the Moorings fleet but also Sunsail’s which is part of the same group.
Now, that is all very well but it has meant the Leopard catamarans can end up getting a bit pigeonholed as pure charter vessels, and this is far from the truth. In reality, the yard has been turning out boats that are good for both charter and private ownership. Mass production has kept costs down and the price of labour in South Africa also helps. All of which this convoluted preamble brings me to the new Leopard 46; first of a new generation of Leopards. It replaces the Leopard 45 which was launched back in 2017 and sold over 400 units. The 46 is a tad bigger and, as with all manufacturers these days, the aim seems to be to offer more space and comfort while not compromising performance. The launch of the 46 also finds the company looking to diversify and underline that it has a product that is well cut out for private ownership. That, I guess, is where I come in. so what have we here? Well, it’s clearly a pure cruising catamaran – there are stub keels as opposed to daggerboards – so this is a boat built to compete with the likes of
Lagoon
, Bali and perhaps
Fountaine Pajot
. Weighing in at 17,000kg, this is not a particularly light boat but, as with all cruising cats these days, you can expect performance to be respectable. As with all Leopards, the design is by Simonis and Voogdt who have a lot of experience in this sector. In terms of construction, the boat is something of a break from the norm for the manufacturer. Whereas previous models used three separate moulds for the hull components then glassed them together, this new boat is built in one single mould which should aid stiffness.
Leopard 46
What is important to understand about this genre of cruising catamarans is that they are capable of quite extraordinary feats. Sailing around the world is far from mission improbable; it has been done many times. By the same token, don’t expect too many thrills; your Lagoons and Leopards etc are competent performers but, ultimately, the autopilot is your friend. Use it and you can enjoy the boat’s finer qualities. One of the other fascinating features of this boat was the electric motors used on the test model. These are an optional extra and are supplied by Alternative Energies, a company that is actually a subsidiary of rival boatbuilder Fountaine Pajot, which has taken the laudable step of making its units available to anyone in an effort to boost innovation and drive costs down. The test boat was equipped with two 25kw electric motors and, of course, all the extra gizmos and batteries that come with that. We’ll get onto the nitty gritty of the electric motors later in the test.
On Deck
You step aboard the boat via broad aft platforms which offer excellent access. The first thing you notice is the huge bathing platform which doubles as storage for the tender. This is one of those elaborate designs that is raised and lowered electrically in order to allow it to be fully submersed for easy launch and recovery of the dinghy. They are clever but both heavy and elaborate and it’s no surprise that this is an optional extra; electric davits are standard. Two steps up and you’re into the cockpit that’s kept completely rope free and is reasonably enclosed with a big L-shaped seating area to port which is ideal for dining in warm weather. There is plentiful seating here, with a long bench seat running latitudinally and enclosing the transom. This seat has a bolster which pivots, meaning you can look at the sea facing aft if you like – a nice touch. To starboard are the steps up to the fly bridge and there is a fridge set into this, while the barbecue is integrated into the coamings to port. It looks neat and is well hidden but is not that well sited as I’d anticipate that smoke from the barbecue would tend to blow into the cockpit.
Leopard 46
Leopard wanted to retain defined indoor and outdoor spaces so, even though there is a large sliding patio door, there is still clear definition between the spaces. Nevertheless, in warm weather, the cockpit itself is a wonderful living space, with the solid Bimini which runs all the way aft, adding protection.
As mentioned, the fly bridge is accessed from the starboard side of the cockpit although there are also steps up from the starboard side deck. The fly bridge is the nerve centre of the 46 and all the sail controls are led here meaning that in theory the boat can be singlehanded with minimum amounts of stress and no need to leave your seat. Catamarans with fly bridges often face a dilemma in that you don’t want to have the skipper too separated off from the lounging area, while also wanting to separate off all the sail controls and have the skipper at a height where he or she can see what’s going on. In the 46, there is a decent connection between the two areas, as the steps up are quite open and offer a clear line of vision if the skipper looks down into the cockpit.
Once installed at the helm, the seat is very comfortable and also sociable as two can sit alongside each other without any stress. The set-up is good with all lines leading back to three powered winches all situated close to the helm. To port of the helm is a bridge deck which, once again, is all about the lounging space. This is accessed from the side decks to port and, as you can imagine, is nicely involved with the skipper’s space while also remaining separate from all the ropes. It’s the ideal spot for a sundowner. Aft of this the solid bimini stretches a long way back and has recesses moulded in that will accommodate solid solar panels. Right aft is the mainsheet on a traveller. The mainsail is at a good height for stowing but it is worth noting that you need to brief crew not to stand on the solar panels which, being the rigid type could get damaged if you tread heavily on them.
Stepping back down to deck level and the side decks are wide, making for a pleasant walkway to the foredeck, although this area can also be accessed via a watertight front door from the main saloon. The foredeck is semi solid with only a small trampoline area. The seating area is in a recessed well with loungers on deck in front and decent storage underneath. The charter versions do not have a bowsprit but the test boat did. All in all, there was a simply vast amount of outdoor space and a good blend of shaded and sunny areas.
Down Below
Head down below and you’re in a big saloon with a lot of light. The windows are apparently the largest in the class and are glass instead of the plexiglass seen on the old Leopard 45. This has less issues with heat expansion than plexiglass according to Leopard. There is a U-shaped seating area to port with its own table that can be folded out to double the width. The galley is to starboard and set well forward with the double sink set against the forward bulkhead latitudinally, and the electric cooker and drawer fridge set longitudinally almost the length of the cabin, only interrupted by the descent into the forward and aft cabins. There is a chart table forward to port and this is large and comfortable with a great seat meaning that it could definitely double as a very pleasant office space.
Leopard 46 interior
Descend down into the starboard hull and the master cabin is set aft with a good sized king sized bed set fore and aft and a heads with separate shower stall. It’s a sensible size and there’s also a small vanity table and a TV making for a very practical and comfortable sleeping area. Forward of this and still to starboard is another double set latitudinally with a narrow heads/shower set right forward. It’s a sensible use of space. The double bed is well raised up which can be a pain to get into in a seaway but this does give you a nice view through the port light.
Leopard 46 interior
The port hull has a double aft which is a good sized bed with partial walkaround access and plentiful light. There is a decent sized ensuite forward to port. Forward of this is a corridor with a washing machine set into the storage units on the starboard side. On this boat there is a utility room which seemed a bit superfluous but good for storage – particularly as it linked to the bow storage compartment. As you can imagine, on the charter version, this can be turned back into a double berth but for bluewater cruising a utility room and all the storage it brings could be a real boon.
Electric Motors
In standard configuration, the 46 is powered by twin 45hp Yanmar diesels although these can be upgraded to 57hp. However, from our point of view, the hybrid electric option on the test boat was of far greater interest. This features twin 25kW electric pods combined with a 24kW range-extending generator and two 27kWh lithium-iron phosphate battery banks. The banks are identical but separate for redundancy should one side fail. Power regeneration is accomplished via shore power, the diesel generator, 1,600 watts of solar panels on the Bimini, and hydrogeneration via the two 18in propellers spinning when under sail. Although regeneration starts at speeds as low as 5kts, you’ll need to sail 8kts or more to generate 1.5-1.8kW per hour per hull.
The key statistic here is that the electric motors give six hours of autonomy at half speed. The solar panels and hydrogeneration are more for domestic power when you’re at anchor. Realistically, you’re going to need to use the generator to replenish those battery banks. That sounds a touch disheartening but it’s worth bearing in mind that the generator is more efficient than a pure diesel motor as it will always run at maximum efficiency for the conditions and requirements of the battery. The cost of the hybrid electric version is circa 200,000 Euros which seems quite a lot but it is worth bearing in mind that you get the whole kit; generator and upgraded lithium ion batteries for this price and these items alone are costly if you take them from the options list but stick with a diesel engine.
Under Sail
Under power the boat is eerily silent when leaving the dock and it is a real pleasure not to have the rumble of the diesel engine in the background. At higher speeds the electric motors make a bit of a whining noise but obviously it’s far, far less than a diesel engine and we easily did 6.5kts. In terms of handling, the powered winches made making sail on a day when there wasn’t a huge amount of breeze at least to start with, an absolute breeze. The steering is cable driven as opposed to hydraulic which gave it a decent amount of feel but it was still relatively uninspiring and the autopilot is definitely your friend. As mentioned, in the early stages of this test, there was not a great deal of wind so it was a good opportunity to play with the electric motors. We experimented with firing up the generator which obviously created some noise but was still markedly quieter than a standard diesel-propelled yacht. In part this was because the generator on the 46 is in the storage area in front of the saloon meaning that you are generally well away from the motor. Going flat out with the electric motors we hit 9.2kts in relatively flat water. That’s not bad going at all although obviously without the generator as backup, you’re going to flatten your batteries relatively rapidly. As the test progressed, the breeze filled in, although it was never more than 10kts. Nevertheless, in these modest conditions, the boat hit 4.5kts on the wind and, easing the sheets we were doing 6.2kts which was good in the fickle conditions.
Leopard 46
Sam’s Verdict
Given that Leopard mass produce these boats, it simply cannot afford to turn out a dud and it has the experience and expertise to ensure this doesn’t happen. The 46 is a great boat for cruising in comfort and works well both as a charter boat or as a privately owned yacht. Performance is good as opposed to exhilarating but that really isn’t what these cruising catamarans are all about. The pricing is very attractive, and if you are interested in shared ownership, then the strong relationship the company has with
Sunsail
/The Moorings makes this a really enticing option.
blue water: 4
/5
Performance: 3
/5
comfort: 5
/5

How to Go Racing in the Caribbean: Chartering for All Skill Levels
Whether you’re a seasoned sailor or a curious novice, racing in the Caribbean is what dreams are made of, offering charter options for all skill levels writes Sue Pelling
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
9 September 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
LV Yachting, RORC, Caribbean 600 race start  |  Photo credit: Alex Turnbull
Race charter in the Caribbean is not only all about sailing in turquoise waters with consistent trade winds and dramatic island backdrops but it’s also about being part of a lively, local tradition. You’ll find that many Caribbean islands that run regattas are major social and cultural events, blending sport, music, food, and island spirit. This cocktail of hard core, adrenaline-driven racing, and legendary rum punch-fuelled après-race parties are what Caribbean regattas are all about because above all they foster unforgettable memories and friendships that will probably last a lifetime.
The main Caribbean race season runs from January to late April, which not only avoids the hurricane season, but also gives overseas visitors plenty of time to make their trip south worthwhile, with many, particularly pro teams, using the Caribbean circuit as an ideal shake down to the forthcoming northern hemisphere race season.
Caribbean race charter  |  Photo credit: Gabe Rovick
There is a packed calendar of regattas to choose from and, thanks to the Caribbean Sailing Association (
CSA
), which promotes each event with its own identity, dates rarely clash, which means you could realistically take part in the whole Caribbean race series.
If however, holiday time is limited, you may want to return to your favourite haunt with events like
St Maarten Heineken Regatta
, the
BVI Spring Regatta & Sailing Festival
, or
Antigua Sailing Week
some of the most popular. For something different, yet equally fun and extremely competitive, maybe consider St Thomas International Regatta or St Barths Bucket.
Given its popularity, there’s a good choice of race yacht charter companies serving the Caribbean and covering events and feeder race/cruises such as the
World Cruising Club Atlantic Rally for Cruisers
(ARC and ARC+) an event which sets off across the Atlantic from Gran Canaria to the Caribbean mid to late November. This means there are many opportunities to sign up for a berth on either a private charter yacht, or charter yacht through companies such as LV Yachting, Go West Sailing, or Firstaway Yacht Charter.
While many companies offer crewed or bareboat charter options, a growing sector is individual berth charter. Sea to Sky Sailing primarily offers individual berth race charter opportunities aboard its race optimised Salona 45,
Panacea X
. Katy Campbell (Sea to Sky Sailing Director and lead race skipper) commented: “We are a frequent feature of the podium across the whole Caribbean circuit, and in 2025 were awarded the Traveler’s Trophy for being the top performing boat of the year. We are usually the only female-skippered boat on the circuit, often the only one flying the maple leaf, and one of the few associated with an RYA training centre.
Antigua English Harbour, Nelson's Dockyard  |  Photo credit: Shutterstock
“For the 2025/2026 Caribbean season, we will be racing in St Lucia’s Mango Bowl, Barbados Sailing Week, Rum to Spice Offshore Race, Grenada Sailing Week, RORC Caribbean 600, St Maarten Heineken Regatta, BVI Regatta and Antigua Sailing Week. We’re looking forward to another great season and look forward to having many familiar faces back on board as well as new crew joining us from all over the world.”
Another popular company is LV Yachting which specialises in race yacht charters across the Caribbean, and is passionate about connecting teams with high-performance yachts – from Volvo Ocean 65s and ORC winners to multihulls and top-tier racer cruisers. LV’s Chris Bruty commenting on what’s on offer said: “We offer whole-boat and crewed charters for events including the RORC Caribbean 600, Heineken Regatta, BVI Spring Regatta, Antigua Sailing Week and more. With 15+ years’ experience, we tailor every charter to the crew’s needs, handling logistics like berthing, race entry, and concierge support. Whether you’re a seasoned campaigner or new to Caribbean regattas, our personalised service ensures a competitive, seamless and unforgettable racing experience.”
As well as being one of the key cruising charter companies, Sunsail also offers a range of race charter options in the Caribbean. Caroline Barbour, Sunsail’s Marketing Manager UK/ZA/AU said: “Our team of expert holiday planners can offer advice on chartering a bareboat or skippered yacht, suitable for seasoned crews and those new to racing. The key events for next season include the BVI Spring Regatta, Antigua Sailing Week, Grenada Sailing Week, and the St Maarten Heineken Regatta.
“Customers benefit from the maintained charter fleet and access to Sunsail’s experienced skippers. It’s an excellent way to gain race entry, shore-side support, and seamless participation in top-tier Caribbean regattas. Off the water, racers enjoy legendary socials, island hospitality, and an unbeatable party atmosphere that comes with every regatta.”
Second Star Sailing, which participates in events such as Grenada Sailing Week, RORC 600 Caribbean, St Maarten Heineken Regatta, and St Barths Bucket also specialises in women’s sailing, and is particularly keen to promote its Women at the Helm in the Caribbean. Second Star Sailing’s Aliya Brown commenting on this popular programme said: “Through our all-women race team programme, Women at the Helm, Second Star Sailing is happy to support women in competitive sailing. Our two-week package is meant to give female sailors more confidence and skills.
“It includes a full week of race training skills to support passionate women in developing their skills in any role on a racing team, whether they are helm, trimmer, bow, or tactician. During the second week, we will be on the water for Antigua Sailing Week, racing with a crew that is excited to share their knowledge. Based in Antigua, we are dedicated to getting more women involved in racing by giving them access, mentoring, and world-class training in a lively regatta setting.”
Finally it’s worth remembering that access to the Caribbean with direct flights from the UK to many islands makes chartering a yacht a good option particularly if leisure time is more restricted. If you are flexible with time, you may be able to find some good last-minute deals, so it’s worth keeping an eye out online (see Useful contacts below).

Cruising Greece to Malta: Bob Shepton Heads to the Med with Environmental Initiative
Noted high latitude explorer Bob Shepton dabbles his toes in the mediterranean and sails from Greece to Malta via Sicily as part of an environmental initiative
Author
:
Bob Shepton
Published Date:
23 December 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
Grand Harbour, Valletta, Malta  |  Photo credit: Adobe Stock
My motives for this trip were varied. I was on the committee that vetted applications for the
Ocean Cruising Club’s Challenge Grant
when Project Manaia had applied for a grant to support their environmental work in the Mediterranean. Then, my generation had no concept that there were dangers to the environment, so I am playing catch up on that score. There again, except for a short passage from Tierra-Veja in southeast Spain to Gibraltar I had never sailed in the Mediterranean – too crowded! And then I had never been back to Malta since I had been stationed there as a young officer in 45 Commando, Royal Marines in the 1950s. So, I joined Project Manaia for their end of season sea passage from Kefalonia to Malta.
The heat hit you as soon as you stepped off the plane. This was
Greece
in late summer after all. Local travel arrangements went well and I was soon aboard in Argostolini bay enjoying a late supper, as to my surprise airlines appear to no longer feed you on board. It showed how far behind the times I was, and a further surprise was a severe downpour of wind and rain in the night. Perhaps the Mediterranean was not going to be such a pushover after all!
Approaching the first anchorage  |  Photo credit: Bob Shepton
Over the next day or two more crew gradually arrived. Each two-week leg through the summer had mostly new crews joining. The reasons why the crews, mainly of young people, were coming were also varied, from some writing their thesis on the basis of the research – it was Project Manaia –
Marine Research Expeditions
, after all – to some having a spare couple of weeks and just liking the idea of sailing and helping the environment. There was quite a mix of nationalities as well.
The Boat
The boat, a steel 19m schooner that rejoiced in the name of
Waya Waya
, was well fitted out for sailing. The rig comprised a furling genoa, with a hanked-on staysail just behind, and then a large insert sail (inter) between the two masts (the boom had been removed), or a small inter sail, and then a mainsail on a boom on the aft mast. So, there were plenty of options to choose from for sailing. But then what seemed extraordinary to a conventional sailor like me, the wheel was entirely unprotected by any form of sprayhood, nor was there any seat or barrier to lean against when steering. There was however, a chart plotter and a powerful autohelm. Clearly heavy weather sailing was to be avoided if possible, and it worked fine in light conditions, though if I had been standing at the wheel for as long as the skipper did, I would have wanted somewhere closer to sit than the side benches.
Slipping down below there was a slight problem re ventilation. This relied on hatches being open but in stormy or rainy conditions these had to be closed. Perhaps something by way of Dorade ventilators would be useful? The skipper had done an excellent job fitting out down below over the years, and he did assure me that he was going to add a handrail fore and aft and athwartships, as at the moment it was easy to be thrown around in the spacious saloon. Something to hang onto when making your way around in the sleeping quarters would also be useful. The boat did have two heads which was helpful with such large crews. The bunks were wide and spacious though again I did miss having some form of leeboard or lee-cloth. It was becoming obvious that the whole emphasis was on the research in quiet conditions, but might not heavy weather be encountered even in the Mediterranean?
Author and skipper discuss whether to raise the International Association of Cape Horner’s burgee
We were anchored in Argostoli bay. I imagine it was typical of most Greek harbours: there were at least two huge three-deckers resting on two large hulls pretending to be yachts, there was a floating block of flats by way of a cruise ship, and then closer to us, more sensible monohulls and catamarans. It was some relief when the skipper checked out and we set sail, all 11 of us on board by now.
In Search of Seagrass
We only went some five miles to begin with and anchored up in a corner by some strange scoured-out sandstone cliffs. Research proceedings commenced. To one completely uninitiated like myself, this was of considerable interest and formed the basis of the research wherever we went. The aim was to examine the seabed by way of transects, that is in straight lines starting from the shore to 50m out, by snorkeling where necessary. Groups, generally of three persons working alongside each other, started from different places round the shore, and the item of basic interest was seagrass – how much of it was there, what state was it in, was anything feeding on it, or what was growing on it, who or what was using it? It rapidly became obvious that seagrass formed the basis of much underwater ecology. And here was I complaining that I wasn’t allowed to put my anchor down in Loch Creran back home because of the seagrass!
All this was meticulously recorded in data banks when they got back to the boat, which were then open to universities and all interested bodies, of which there seemed to be quite a number. And this procedure was followed wherever we stopped and anchored, whether near a town or in open country. Sometimes it was a case of making new transepts, sometimes they were made over the top of old transepts so comparisons from former times could be made. Conscientious and meticulous research and recording was carried out each time. Lucky the water was warm and inviting for swimming.
Across the Med
But now the time had come for the sea passage, which had been the main attraction for me signing on. But should we go via Syracuse, Sicily, and then on to Malta, or to Malta direct? Let the wind decide. I had already been introduced to another form of data analysis, above the water this time. Folk on rotas were posted port, bow, starboard and aft with a writer to record any sightings of seabirds, how many and what type, and anything else of interest in the water such as dolphins. I have to confess I did sometimes think, give it a rest and let’s get on with the sailing, but that was definitely me at fault. The whole aim of this boat was the research; the sailing was just a backup.
So, we set sail westwards for Sicily or Malta and very pleasant it was. From memory we had the main set on the aft boom with one reef in because of a high wind forecast (which did not materialise until later) and the small inter permanently set. Sometimes we had both the staysail and the genoa flying, sometimes just the genoa. The sun shone by day and the blue dome of the sky was clear except for the line of those small white puffy cumulus clouds along the horizon, a sure sign of fair weather. There was a watch system, the crew broken down into three groups under those of us who had done a little more sailing. Personally, I did find four-hour watches at night a bit of a strain, but then I had for years organised my crews into two-hour watches on my own boat. The skipper set it all up, put the course into the autohelm, and really all we had to do was to call him if anything changed. Not too exacting!
Welcome to Sicily
Conditions did change. For a while we had to motor. Then back on sail and latterly the wind increased but we did not have to change the sail plan we had by then, genoa, big inter and reefed main. We could still hold a course for Syracuse on Sicily. We approached in the early hours, following down a flashing lighthouse, finally putting the engine on in the morning daylight to motor quite a way still to the shore, to put our anchor down. Welcome to Sicily.
Plans for transects, cruising greece to malta  |  Photo credit: Bob Shepton
Again, at every stop transects were undertaken, and observations made round the boat when moving. Fontane Blanche and Porto Palo are names that come to mind where we stopped in Sicily, and we finally took our departure for Malta from Capo Passero on the southern tip. An uneventful 70nm crossing had us doing more transepts in Malta at Selmon, Ingiebeach and even in St Julien’s Bay just north of Valletta, right off the town itself. But the skipper had been saving up the entrance to Valletta itself as the grand finale, and he was right, As we turned to face towards the town itself, we were confronted with a scene that had not changed in a thousand years. Those Knights Templar certainly did not want anybody to think it worthwhile to attack their city; massive walls and defences that have been there for centuries, untouched and unchanged. Were they also a solace in World War 2 to submariners returning from enduring yet another prolonged depth charge attack? Sidling past the ships of the Maltese navy to reach the marina after that was something of an anti-climax. But we duly took our designated position on an outside pontoon and that was the end of the sailing for me.
Setting out to set up a transect  |  Photo credit: Bob Shepton
I undertook one expedition in Malta, accompanied by the dear girl who was cook and anchor lady on board (I never quite understood how those two responsibilities married up!), who was a nurse and about the same age as my nursing granddaughter back home, so there was an immediate rapprochement. She kindly took me in hand and saw that I was alright throughout the trip, and now we went off by bus – an adventure in itself – to look for the site of the old military camp at the northern end of the island by Ghajn Tuffieha, where I had been stationed 70 years ago to the exact year! We thought we
might
have found the site, though with all the modern building and luxury hotels it was difficult to be sure.
In fact, the care, concern and attention of all the crew to having a 90-year oldie on board was superb and could not be bettered. So, what of the future – if I were to be invited again? It was a completely different form of sailing. I did catch myself wondering at one point whether a day or some time at least could be devoted to introducing these highly intelligent young people, some of whom had never sailed before, to the rudiments of sailing – steering the boat, setting the sails according to the wind direction and other basic points. It was only a passing thought; the whole purpose and basis of the project was the environmental research. I learnt a lot as a result but concluded it would probably be best to stick to sailing while being grateful there was hope for the planet yet!
Cruising Greece to Malta - group photo  |  Photo credit: Bob Shepton

Premier Falmouth Marina: Guide and Cruising Grounds
The Premier Falmouth Marina is Picturesque, well appointed, and conveniently positioned for serious west country cruising and beyond...
Author
:
Sue Pelling
Published Date:
18 August 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
The marina is sheltered and well appointed. Credit: Premier Marinas
As far as locations go, the Premier Falmouth Marina is one of the most picturesque you’ll find. It is also well appointed, and conveniently positioned for serious west country cruising and beyond, says Sue Pelling.
50° 09’90N, 005°05’02W
The vibrant and historic town of Falmouth in Cornwall, which is located within an area of outstanding natural beauty is one of the most desirable places to visit when cruising the west country. Given its popularity there are plenty of sheltered berthing options available including Premier’s Falmouth Marina, which sits conveniently on the south bank up Penryn River.
The main Falmouth harbour, as you enter from the Channel – Carrick Roads – is one of the world’s largest natural deep-water harbours and extends northwards as far as the River Fal. In the 18th century it became a bustling hub for packet ships carrying mail, and other commercial goods including  timber, iron, coal, and charcoal. It was also an important harbour for the arrival of imported goods such as tea, spices and silks. Falmouth’s defence role in both world wars was crucial too because it served as a base for anti-submarine operations as well as an embarkation point for the D-Day landings.
Falmouth’s rich maritime heritage continues to be celebrated to this day with events such as the Falmouth Regatta,
Falmouth Classics
, the Oyster Festival, and the Falmouth International Sea Shanty Festival taking place every year. Falmouth Marina is within easy walking distance to the main hub which is home to a vast array of independent shops, restaurants and attractions such as Discovery Quay, the National Maritime Museum, and Pendennis Castle.
When you arrive at the marina you can be sure of a warm welcome by Premier’s staff who are on hand 24-hours a day to assist you with your berthing, and any help you require with facilities. As with all Premier Marinas, Falmouth Marina is well designed and laid out for ease of use. It has two berthing areas, with space for boats up to 18m loa on its outer pontoons, and up to 15m loa in its inner basin. For convenience it has a chandlery and restaurant (UpperDeck), and fuel bay for diesel onsite, and has a full-service boatyard as well as a range of businesses including a sailmaker, marine electronic specialist, a rigger, and a yacht broker.
Annual berth holders can also benefit from Premier Advantage, which offers a package of rewards, benefits and cost savings including 42 free visitor nights and unlimited short stays at any Premier marina, Sea Start benefits and savings, fuel at cost, special deals on insurance, and up to eight.
Passage Planning
The marina’s location on the south bank of the Penryn River (the first creek you see on the western side of the Fal Estuary) offers easy access but if your boat has a draft of 1.7m, avoid making the approach within 1.5 hours of low water springs. The channel is buoyed and the general approach to the marina is straightforward but it is, however, advisable to consult up-to-date charts, and check notes to mariners at the time of arrival in case of any changes.
The access channel is to the southwest of the east cardinal mark. Travel upstream, leaving Greenbank Quay to port. You will see the marina as you pass Boyers Cellars – a deep-water commercial jetty. Steer close to the marina’s outer pontoons, keeping between them and the east cardinal beacon, which shows the edge of the dredged area.
When you arrive, moor at the visitors’ hammerhead pontoon and call up reception on VHF Ch80 or using the pontoon telephone for berth allocation.
It is also worth noting the marina is divided in two by a cill that is marked at each end by a tide gauge. The cill dries to 1.8m above Chart Datum and visitors should only enter the inner basin after being given the go-ahead by marina staff. Finally, if you are a visitor, Premier says it strongly advises pre-booking, especially in peak season because it gives priority access to Premier berth holders visiting from other marinas.
Cruising Grounds
Once in the Fal estuary and you base yourself at the marina, you have 12nm of cruising options, stretching as far as the cathedral city of Truro, to explore. With beautiful wooded shorelines and plenty of creeks and places of interest to visit along the way, there’s hardly any need to go anywhere else. Take a sail round to Trelissick for example, where you can anchor off and visit the National Trust Trelissick house and gardens and enjoy the spectacular views. If you are intending to venture further afield to places like the Isles of Scilly, which is approximately 60nm away, or across the Channel, it’s an ideal safe, sheltered base. There are plenty of popular shorter passages on the ‘doorstep’ too including (to the east) the pretty town of Fowey just 20nm away, Plymouth 38nm away, or Salcombe in Devon 50nm. One of the most delightful places just south around the headland is the Helford River. This is a gem of a place to explore because it’s off the beaten track and offers stunning scenery, plenty of interesting anchorages, and attractive beaches particularly on the north shore of the Helford estuary.
Further afield, Jersey and the Channel Islands are logical destinations.

2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show: What to Look Forward To
The 2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show is on the horizon... Here’s what’s new!
Author
:
Milly Karsten
Published Date:
19 December 2025
SHARE THIS ARTICLE
2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show  |  Photo credit: RYA
On 21st-22nd February 2026, Farnborough International is set to host the UK’s biggest celebration of dinghy sailing and watersports. Covering cruising, windsurfing, dinghy sailing, paddleboarding and winging, the show will bring the marine industry together and showcase the latest innovations across the sport - a brilliant way to kick off 2026!
What to Look Forward to at the 2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show
From new boats and cutting edge tech, to expert coaching sessions from leading names in the sport, this year’s show brings you a weekend of innovation and inspiration.
The 2026 programme is jam packed with exciting talks, demos, simulators and interactive displays and, this year, the show welcomes wingfoiler and presenter Rafferty Read to the hosting line-up.
RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show  |  Photo credit: RYA
The brand new feature we are looking forward to is the NextGen Zone, a designated space for young sailors and watersports lovers to get stuck into workshops and sessions designed to build the next generation’s confidence and skills.
“What makes the RYA Dinghy & Watersports Show so special is how it unites the whole community. From dinghy racers and windsurfers to paddleboarders and foilers, top names in our sport and the best marine brands – everyone’s ready and willing to share their knowledge to set you up for success,” said Show Manager Celia Edgington.
RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show  |  Photo credit: RYA
From trying the trapeze rig and wing, and experiencing sailing simulators or the on-the-water 360 virtual reality, to boat repair workshops and grabbing some brand new kit, the 2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show is one you won’t want to miss!
For the Family…
As in years before, the show is a perfect weekend activity for the whole family. Bringing young visitors together, the ever-popular Treasure Hunt invites little ones to keep on the lookout for their favourite marine wildlife, collecting clues and stickers throughout the show, with a chance to win some brilliant prizes.
RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show  |  Photo credit: RYA
Tickets
To book your ticket,
visit the 2026 RYA Dinghy and Watersports Show website
. Prices start from £15 (children under 15 go free with a ticketed adult).
RYA members
are able to access a free two-day ticket.
Photo credit: RYA
